name: Digital Citizenship and Online Safety
short_description: Students develop responsible digital behaviors, understand online safety principles, protect personal information, and navigate digital environments ethically and securely.

sub_topics.name: Digital Literacy Fundamentals
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding basic digital skills, evaluating online information, and using technology effectively for learning and communication.

sub_topics.name: Evaluating Online Information
sub_topics.short_description: Critically assessing credibility, accuracy, and bias of digital content and sources.
example_tasks: Compare three websites about the same topic and identify which sources are most credible based on author credentials, publication date, and evidence provided
Identify signs of misinformation in a social media post by checking facts against reliable sources and analyzing the purpose of the content
Create a checklist of criteria for evaluating website reliability including domain type, author expertise, citation of sources, and potential bias

sub_topics.name: Digital Footprint and Online Reputation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how online actions create a permanent digital footprint and impact future opportunities.
example_tasks: Research your own digital footprint by searching your name online and documenting what information is publicly available about you
Analyze case studies of how social media posts have positively or negatively affected people's college admissions or job opportunities
Create a presentation about strategies for managing your online reputation including privacy settings, appropriate posting, and professional profiles

sub_topics.name: Digital Communication and Netiquette
sub_topics.short_description: Practicing appropriate, respectful, and effective communication in digital environments.
example_tasks: Rewrite inappropriate emails or messages to demonstrate proper tone, grammar, and professionalism for different contexts (teacher, friend, employer)
Participate in an online discussion forum following netiquette rules including staying on topic, being respectful, and citing sources
Create a guide for effective video conferencing including proper setup, background, attire, and participation etiquette

sub_topics.name: Cybersecurity Awareness and Protection
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying online threats, implementing security measures, and protecting devices and personal information from cyber attacks.

sub_topics.name: Password Security and Authentication
sub_topics.short_description: Creating strong passwords, using password managers, and implementing multi-factor authentication.
example_tasks: Evaluate password strength by testing passwords in a password checker tool and identifying characteristics that make passwords strong or weak
Set up two-factor authentication on a school account and explain how this additional security layer protects against unauthorized access
Create a secure password strategy using passphrases, password managers, and unique passwords for different accounts while avoiding common mistakes

sub_topics.name: Phishing and Scam Recognition
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying fraudulent emails, messages, and websites designed to steal information or money.
example_tasks: Analyze sample phishing emails and identify red flags such as suspicious sender addresses, urgent language, grammatical errors, and suspicious links
Create an educational poster warning peers about common online scams targeting middle school students including fake giveaways and impersonation
Practice safe link verification by hovering over hyperlinks, checking URLs before clicking, and using website security indicators like HTTPS

sub_topics.name: Malware and Device Protection
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding malware types, using antivirus software, and maintaining secure devices.
example_tasks: Research different types of malware (viruses, trojans, ransomware, spyware) and create a chart comparing how each works and how to prevent infection
Perform a security audit on a school computer by checking for software updates, antivirus status, and firewall settings
Develop a monthly device maintenance checklist including software updates, antivirus scans, backup procedures, and security setting reviews

sub_topics.name: Privacy and Personal Information Protection
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding privacy rights, managing personal data, and controlling information shared online.

sub_topics.name: Privacy Settings and Controls
sub_topics.short_description: Configuring privacy settings on social media, apps, and devices to limit data sharing.
example_tasks: Audit privacy settings on a social media account and adjust who can see posts, contact information, and location data
Compare privacy policies of three popular apps to identify what data they collect, how they use it, and who they share it with
Create a guide for configuring smartphone privacy settings including location services, app permissions, and data sharing options

sub_topics.name: Online Tracking and Data Collection
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how websites and companies track online behavior and collect user data.
example_tasks: Install a browser extension that blocks trackers and analyze how many trackers are present on popular websites you visit
Research how cookies work and demonstrate clearing browser cookies while explaining the difference between session and tracking cookies
Investigate how targeted advertising works by examining ads you see online and identifying what data might have been used to select them

sub_topics.name: Safe Sharing of Personal Information
sub_topics.short_description: Making informed decisions about what personal information to share online and with whom.
example_tasks: Create a decision flowchart for determining whether it's safe to share specific types of information (name, age, school, address, photos) in different online contexts
Analyze Terms of Service agreements from websites used by middle schoolers and identify concerning data collection or sharing practices
Role-play scenarios where strangers online request personal information and practice appropriate responses including blocking and reporting

sub_topics.name: Ethical and Responsible Technology Use
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding intellectual property, avoiding plagiarism, respecting others' work, and using technology ethically.

sub_topics.name: Copyright and Fair Use
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding copyright law, fair use guidelines, and proper attribution of digital content.
example_tasks: Determine whether specific scenarios represent fair use of copyrighted material in educational projects by applying the four fair use factors
Create a multimedia project properly citing images, music, and video clips while using Creative Commons or public domain resources
Research copyright laws related to downloading music, movies, and software and present the legal and ethical implications of piracy

sub_topics.name: Plagiarism Prevention and Citation
sub_topics.short_description: Avoiding plagiarism by properly citing sources and creating original work.
example_tasks: Rewrite plagiarized paragraphs to demonstrate proper paraphrasing and citation of sources in MLA or APA format
Use plagiarism detection tools to check written work and understand how to correctly incorporate and cite source material
Create a bibliography for a research project including websites, books, videos, and images with proper formatting and attribution

sub_topics.name: Cyberbullying Prevention and Digital Respect
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing cyberbullying, responding appropriately, and treating others respectfully online.
example_tasks: Analyze case studies of cyberbullying incidents and identify appropriate responses for targets, witnesses, and platforms
Create an anti-cyberbullying campaign for your school including posters, videos, or presentations about recognizing and reporting bullying
Practice being an upstander by role-playing scenarios where you witness mean or inappropriate online behavior and choose supportive responses

sub_topics.name: Social Impact of Technology
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how technology affects society, equity, accessibility, and environmental sustainability.
example_tasks: Research the digital divide and present how unequal access to technology affects educational and economic opportunities
Investigate accessibility features in technology (screen readers, closed captions, voice control) and test how well websites accommodate users with disabilities
Analyze the environmental impact of technology including e-waste, energy consumption, and sustainable computing practices

name: Computer Systems and Hardware
short_description: Students learn about computer components, how hardware and software interact, operating system functions, file organization, and basic troubleshooting techniques.

sub_topics.name: Computer Hardware Components
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the function of internal and external computer components and how they work together.

sub_topics.name: Internal Hardware Components
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying and understanding the purpose of components inside a computer case.
example_tasks: Label a diagram of the inside of a computer identifying the CPU, motherboard, RAM, hard drive, power supply, and graphics card
Research the function of the CPU and explain how clock speed, cores, and cache affect computer performance
Compare specifications of two computers (RAM, storage, processor) and determine which would be better for specific tasks like gaming, video editing, or word processing

sub_topics.name: Input and Output Devices
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding devices used to input data into computers and receive output from them.
example_tasks: Create a chart categorizing computer peripherals as input devices (keyboard, mouse, scanner, microphone) or output devices (monitor, printer, speakers)
Test different input methods (keyboard, touchscreen, voice recognition, gesture control) and compare their efficiency for different tasks
Design an adaptive technology solution for someone with limited mobility by researching and proposing appropriate input and output devices

sub_topics.name: Storage Devices and Memory
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding different types of storage, the difference between storage and memory, and data capacity units.
example_tasks: Compare and contrast RAM (temporary memory) and hard drive storage (permanent storage) explaining why both are needed in a computer system
Calculate storage capacity needs by determining how many photos, songs, or documents can fit on devices with different capacities (GB vs TB)
Research the differences between HDD and SSD storage and explain the advantages and disadvantages of each type

sub_topics.name: Operating Systems and Software
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the role of operating systems, types of software, and how software and hardware interact.

sub_topics.name: Operating System Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding what operating systems do and how they manage computer resources.
example_tasks: Identify the operating system on classroom computers (Windows, macOS, Chrome OS, Linux) and list its key features and interface elements
Use Task Manager or Activity Monitor to observe how the operating system manages running processes, memory usage, and CPU allocation
Research and compare three major operating systems explaining their typical uses, advantages, and disadvantages

sub_topics.name: Types of Software
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between system software, application software, and understanding software licensing.
example_tasks: Create a categorized inventory of software on a school computer separating system software, productivity applications, and specialized programs
Compare proprietary software, freeware, shareware, and open-source software using examples and explaining licensing differences
Research software version numbers and update processes, then demonstrate checking for and installing software updates

sub_topics.name: Software Installation and Management
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how to safely install, update, and uninstall software applications.
example_tasks: Follow installation procedures for approved educational software including reading permissions, choosing installation options, and verifying successful installation
Use application management tools to view installed programs, check version numbers, and safely uninstall unnecessary applications
Create a guide for recognizing legitimate software downloads versus potentially harmful fake downloads or bundled software

sub_topics.name: File Management and Organization
sub_topics.short_description: Organizing files and folders, understanding file types and extensions, and managing digital storage efficiently.

sub_topics.name: File and Folder Organization
sub_topics.short_description: Creating logical folder structures and organizing digital files for easy retrieval.
example_tasks: Design and implement a folder structure for school work organized by subject, year, and assignment type
Practice using file management operations including creating folders, moving files, renaming items, and using search functions
Audit a disorganized collection of files and reorganize them into a logical structure with descriptive folder and file names

sub_topics.name: File Types and Extensions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding different file formats, their uses, and how to work with various file types.
example_tasks: Create a reference guide of common file extensions (.docx, .pdf, .jpg, .mp4, .xlsx) explaining what each type is used for and which programs open them
Convert files between different formats (image to PDF, document to PDF, video formats) and explain when and why format conversion is necessary
Identify appropriate file formats for different purposes such as sharing documents, preserving image quality, or reducing file size

sub_topics.name: Backup and File Recovery
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the importance of backups and implementing strategies to protect important data.
example_tasks: Demonstrate backing up important files to cloud storage or external drive and explain the 3-2-1 backup rule
Practice recovering accidentally deleted files from the recycle bin or cloud storage trash folders
Create a personal backup plan including what files to backup, how often, where to store backups, and how to test restoration

sub_topics.name: Cloud Storage and Synchronization
sub_topics.short_description: Using cloud storage services to store, share, and synchronize files across devices.
example_tasks: Set up a cloud storage account (Google Drive, OneDrive, Dropbox) and organize school files with appropriate folder sharing permissions
Share a document via cloud storage with specific permissions (view only, comment, edit) and collaborate on a group project
Compare cloud storage versus local storage discussing advantages like accessibility and synchronization versus disadvantages like internet dependency and privacy

sub_topics.name: Basic Troubleshooting and Maintenance
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying common computer problems, applying systematic troubleshooting methods, and performing routine maintenance.

sub_topics.name: Systematic Troubleshooting Process
sub_topics.short_description: Using a methodical approach to identify and resolve computer issues.
example_tasks: Apply a troubleshooting flowchart to diagnose why a computer won't start, checking power, connections, and error messages systematically
Document a computer problem including symptoms, steps already tried, error messages, and eventual solution for future reference
Practice the basic troubleshooting mantra of 'restart, reconnect, research' to solve common issues like frozen programs or connectivity problems

sub_topics.name: Common Hardware and Software Issues
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing and resolving frequently encountered computer problems.
example_tasks: Troubleshoot common software issues including programs freezing, slow performance, and application crashes using task manager and restart procedures
Diagnose and fix simple connectivity problems with peripherals like printers, mice, or external drives by checking cables and drivers
Research solutions to error messages by searching online technical support forums and evaluating which solutions are safe and applicable

sub_topics.name: System Maintenance and Optimization
sub_topics.short_description: Performing regular maintenance tasks to keep computers running efficiently.
example_tasks: Create and follow a monthly computer maintenance schedule including disk cleanup, update checks, and clearing temporary files
Use built-in system tools to optimize performance such as defragmentation (HDD), disk cleanup, and startup program management
Monitor computer performance using system monitoring tools and identify processes or programs consuming excessive resources

name: Networks and Internet Technologies
short_description: Students explore network fundamentals, internet architecture, communication protocols, wireless technologies, and how data travels across networks.

sub_topics.name: Network Fundamentals and Types
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding what networks are, different network types, and basic networking concepts.

sub_topics.name: Types of Networks
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between LAN, WAN, and other network configurations.
example_tasks: Create a diagram comparing LAN (Local Area Network) in a school versus WAN (Wide Area Network) connecting multiple schools, labeling components
Identify examples of different network types in daily life such as home Wi-Fi (LAN), cellular networks (WAN), and the internet
Design a network plan for a small business determining whether devices should be on the same LAN and how to connect to the internet

sub_topics.name: Network Hardware Components
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding routers, switches, modems, and other networking equipment.
example_tasks: Label a home or school network diagram identifying the modem, router, switch, access points, and connected devices
Explain the difference between a modem (connects to ISP) and a router (creates local network and manages traffic)
Research and compare wired network components (Ethernet cables, network switches) versus wireless components (Wi-Fi routers, access points)

sub_topics.name: Network Topologies and Structures
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how devices can be arranged and connected in networks.
example_tasks: Draw and label different network topologies (star, bus, ring, mesh) explaining advantages and disadvantages of each
Identify the topology used in your school network and explain why that structure was chosen
Simulate network topology failures and predict which connections would be affected in different topology types

sub_topics.name: Internet Architecture and Protocols
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how the internet works, client-server models, and communication protocols.

sub_topics.name: How the Internet Works
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the global network of networks and how data travels across the internet.
example_tasks: Trace the path of data from your computer to a website using tools like traceroute and explain each hop in the journey
Research and create an infographic showing how data travels from a user's device through ISPs, backbone networks, and servers
Explain using an analogy how the internet is a 'network of networks' with no central control point

sub_topics.name: IP Addresses and Domain Name System
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how devices are identified on networks and how domain names work.
example_tasks: Find the IP address of your computer and explain the difference between public and private IP addresses
Use DNS lookup tools to find the IP address associated with a domain name and explain how DNS translates human-readable names
Compare IPv4 and IPv6 addressing systems including address format, total available addresses, and why IPv6 is needed

sub_topics.name: Network Protocols and TCP/IP
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding communication rules and the protocol stack that enables internet communication.
example_tasks: Explain the difference between TCP (reliable delivery) and UDP (faster but less reliable) and give examples of when each is used
Diagram the TCP/IP protocol stack layers (Application, Transport, Internet, Network Access) and explain the role of each layer
Research common protocols (HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, SMTP, DNS) and explain what each is used for in network communication

sub_topics.name: Client-Server Model
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how clients request services and servers provide them in networked systems.
example_tasks: Identify client and server roles in common online activities like browsing websites, sending email, or streaming video
Simulate client-server communication by having one computer request a webpage and another serve the HTML files
Compare client-server architecture to peer-to-peer networks explaining advantages and use cases for each model

sub_topics.name: Connectivity and Wireless Technologies
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how devices connect to networks including wireless technologies and troubleshooting connections.

sub_topics.name: Wi-Fi and Wireless Networking
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how wireless networks function, security, and configuration.
example_tasks: Connect a device to a Wi-Fi network and explain the authentication process including SSID, password, and encryption types (WPA2, WPA3)
Compare 2.4GHz and 5GHz Wi-Fi bands including range, speed, and interference characteristics
Research wireless security best practices including strong passwords, hiding SSID, MAC filtering, and guest network setup

sub_topics.name: Bluetooth and Mobile Connectivity
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding short-range wireless technologies and mobile network connections.
example_tasks: Pair a Bluetooth device with a computer or phone and explain the pairing process and when Bluetooth is preferable to Wi-Fi
Compare different mobile data technologies (3G, 4G, 5G) in terms of speed, latency, and typical uses
Investigate how mobile hotspots work and set up a device to share its mobile data connection with other devices

sub_topics.name: Network Troubleshooting
sub_topics.short_description: Diagnosing and resolving common network connectivity issues.
example_tasks: Troubleshoot why a device cannot connect to Wi-Fi by checking network availability, password, airplane mode, and network adapter settings
Use network diagnostic tools like ping and ipconfig/ifconfig to test connectivity and identify where connection problems occur
Create a troubleshooting flowchart for network issues including checking physical connections, restarting router/modem, and contacting ISP

sub_topics.name: Web Technologies and Services
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how web browsers work, web protocols, and internet services.

sub_topics.name: Web Browsers and URLs
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding browser functions, URL structure, and how web pages are requested and displayed.
example_tasks: Dissect a URL identifying the protocol (https://), domain name, path, and parameters, explaining what each part means
Compare different web browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge) in terms of features, speed, and privacy options
Use browser developer tools to view the HTTP requests and responses when loading a webpage

sub_topics.name: HTTP and HTTPS Protocols
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding web communication protocols and the importance of secure connections.
example_tasks: Identify secure (HTTPS) versus unsecure (HTTP) websites and explain why encryption is important for sensitive information
View SSL certificate information for a website and interpret what the certificate tells you about the site's identity and security
Research how HTTPS works including the role of encryption, certificates, and why browsers warn about insecure sites

sub_topics.name: Internet Services and Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding common internet services like email, file transfer, and streaming.
example_tasks: Map out how email works from sender to recipient including SMTP (sending), POP3/IMAP (receiving), and mail servers
Compare different methods of file sharing including email attachments, FTP, cloud storage, and peer-to-peer explaining trade-offs
Investigate how streaming services deliver video content including buffering, adaptive bitrate, and bandwidth requirements

sub_topics.name: Bandwidth and Network Performance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding factors that affect internet speed and network performance.
example_tasks: Test internet connection speed using online speed test tools and interpret download speed, upload speed, and latency results
Calculate how long it would take to download files of different sizes at various connection speeds
Identify factors affecting network performance such as bandwidth limitations, network congestion, distance from router, and simultaneous users

name: Introduction to Programming Concepts
short_description: Students develop computational thinking skills, understand fundamental programming concepts like algorithms, variables, and data types, and learn problem decomposition.

sub_topics.name: Computational Thinking
sub_topics.short_description: Developing problem-solving approaches including decomposition, pattern recognition, abstraction, and algorithm design.

sub_topics.name: Problem Decomposition
sub_topics.short_description: Breaking complex problems into smaller, manageable sub-problems.
example_tasks: Break down the task of making a peanut butter and jelly sandwich into individual steps detailed enough for someone who has never seen one
Decompose a complex problem like planning a class party into smaller tasks such as choosing a date, creating a guest list, and selecting food
Analyze a video game and identify the smaller sub-systems that work together such as character movement, scoring, collision detection, and level design

sub_topics.name: Pattern Recognition
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying similarities and patterns in problems to develop general solutions.
example_tasks: Identify patterns in number sequences and write a rule to generate the next number or any number in the sequence
Compare multiple similar problems (calculating areas of different shapes) and recognize the common pattern of multiplying dimensions
Analyze repeated behaviors in daily routines and identify patterns that could be automated with technology

sub_topics.name: Abstraction
sub_topics.short_description: Focusing on important information while ignoring irrelevant details.
example_tasks: Create a subway map showing only station connections and lines, demonstrating abstraction by removing geographic detail
Design an abstract model of a school showing only classrooms and how students move between them, ignoring furniture and decorations
Compare a photograph to a simple icon of the same object explaining what details were abstracted away and why

sub_topics.name: Algorithm Design
sub_topics.short_description: Creating step-by-step procedures to solve problems effectively.
example_tasks: Write an algorithm for finding the largest number in a list of numbers, testing it with different examples
Create a flowchart algorithm for deciding what to wear based on the weather and daily activities
Design an algorithm to sort a deck of cards and compare it to other sorting methods discussing efficiency

sub_topics.name: Algorithms and Pseudocode
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding what algorithms are, writing pseudocode, and analyzing algorithm efficiency.

sub_topics.name: Algorithm Fundamentals
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the properties of algorithms including input, output, definiteness, and finiteness.
example_tasks: Evaluate whether a set of instructions constitutes a valid algorithm by checking for clear steps, defined inputs/outputs, and guaranteed termination
Compare two algorithms that solve the same problem in different ways and discuss which is more efficient or easier to understand
Identify algorithms in everyday life such as recipes, assembly instructions, or directions and analyze their components

sub_topics.name: Writing Pseudocode
sub_topics.short_description: Expressing algorithms in plain language before coding them.
example_tasks: Write pseudocode for calculating the average of three test scores including input, processing, and output steps
Translate a written description of a process into structured pseudocode using keywords like BEGIN, END, IF, THEN, WHILE
Convert pseudocode into a flowchart and vice versa to practice multiple ways of representing algorithms

sub_topics.name: Flowcharts and Visual Algorithms
sub_topics.short_description: Representing algorithms visually using flowchart symbols and conventions.
example_tasks: Create a flowchart for an algorithm using proper symbols for start/end (oval), process (rectangle), decision (diamond), and flow (arrows)
Trace through a flowchart with sample data to verify it produces the correct output
Design a flowchart for a game or interactive program showing different paths based on user choices

sub_topics.name: Algorithm Efficiency and Comparison
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that different algorithms can solve the same problem with varying efficiency.
example_tasks: Compare linear search versus binary search by counting how many steps each takes to find a number in a sorted list
Analyze two sorting algorithms (like bubble sort and selection sort) and discuss trade-offs between simplicity and speed
Measure how algorithm efficiency changes as input size increases by testing with lists of different lengths

sub_topics.name: Variables and Data Types
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding variables as containers for data and different types of data that programs use.

sub_topics.name: Variable Concepts and Naming
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding what variables are, how they store data, and conventions for naming them.
example_tasks: Explain the concept of a variable as a labeled box that holds a value that can change during program execution
Evaluate variable names for clarity and convention (descriptive, camelCase or snake_case, no spaces, meaningful)
Practice declaring and initializing variables with appropriate names for different purposes like score, userName, or totalPrice

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Data Types
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding different categories of data including integers, floats, strings, and booleans.
example_tasks: Categorize values as integers (whole numbers), floats (decimals), strings (text), or booleans (true/false) and explain differences
Predict what happens when you try to perform mathematical operations with different data types like adding a number to a string
Choose appropriate data types for storing different kinds of information such as age (integer), name (string), or price (float)

sub_topics.name: Type Conversion and Casting
sub_topics.short_description: Converting between different data types when needed in programs.
example_tasks: Convert user input from a string to an integer or float to perform calculations with it
Practice converting between types and identify situations where conversion fails or produces unexpected results
Debug programs where type mismatches cause errors and fix them with appropriate type conversions

sub_topics.name: Operators and Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Using arithmetic, comparison, and logical operators to create expressions and make calculations.

sub_topics.name: Arithmetic Operators
sub_topics.short_description: Performing mathematical calculations using addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.
example_tasks: Write expressions using +, -, *, /, and % operators and predict results following order of operations
Use the modulus operator (%) to determine if numbers are even or odd or to find remainders
Create expressions that solve practical problems like calculating total cost with tax or converting temperatures

sub_topics.name: Comparison and Relational Operators
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing values using operators like equal to, greater than, and less than.
example_tasks: Write expressions using comparison operators (==, !=, <, >, <=, >=) and evaluate them as true or false
Create conditions for decision-making such as checking if a score is passing or if age is appropriate for a rating
Debug common mistakes like using = instead of == for comparison or confusing the order of operands

sub_topics.name: Logical Operators
sub_topics.short_description: Combining conditions using AND, OR, and NOT to create complex logic.
example_tasks: Combine multiple conditions using AND, OR, and NOT operators to create complex decision logic
Create truth tables showing all possible outcomes when combining boolean values with logical operators
Write compound conditions for real scenarios like 'user is a teenager AND has parental permission' for website access

sub_topics.name: String Operations
sub_topics.short_description: Manipulating text including concatenation, length, and accessing characters.
example_tasks: Concatenate strings together using the + operator to build sentences or messages from parts
Find the length of strings and access individual characters by position (indexing)
Practice string methods like converting to uppercase/lowercase, finding substrings, or replacing text

name: Block-Based and Visual Programming
short_description: Students learn programming fundamentals through visual coding environments like Scratch, focusing on sequences, loops, conditionals, and creating interactive projects.

sub_topics.name: Scratch Programming Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Getting started with Scratch, understanding the interface, sprites, and basic block categories.

sub_topics.name: Scratch Interface and Environment
sub_topics.short_description: Navigating the Scratch editor including stage, sprite area, blocks palette, and scripts area.
example_tasks: Create a Scratch account and explore the interface identifying the stage, sprite list, blocks palette, and scripts area
Add sprites from the library and upload custom sprites, then position them on the stage using coordinates
Explore different block categories (Motion, Looks, Sound, Events, Control, Sensing, Operators, Variables) and understand their purposes

sub_topics.name: Sprites, Costumes, and Backdrops
sub_topics.short_description: Creating and customizing sprites, using costumes for animation, and changing backdrops.
example_tasks: Create a custom sprite using the paint editor and design multiple costumes to create an animation effect
Import sprites and edit their costumes to create different appearances or animation frames
Change backdrops to create different scenes or levels in a project using backdrop switching blocks

sub_topics.name: Coordinate System and Movement
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the Scratch coordinate grid and using it to position and move sprites.
example_tasks: Use the coordinate grid to precisely position sprites at specific x and y locations on the stage
Program a sprite to move to specific coordinates or change position by relative amounts
Create a program where a sprite follows the mouse pointer or moves to random positions using coordinates

sub_topics.name: Sequences and Events
sub_topics.short_description: Creating programs that execute blocks in order and respond to events like clicks or key presses.

sub_topics.name: Sequential Execution
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that blocks execute in order from top to bottom.
example_tasks: Create a simple animation sequence where a sprite changes position, size, and color in a specific order
Debug a program where blocks are out of order causing incorrect behavior and fix the sequence
Write a script that tells a story with sequential dialogue using say blocks

sub_topics.name: Event-Driven Programming
sub_topics.short_description: Using event blocks to start scripts when specific events occur.
example_tasks: Program sprites to respond to the green flag click, key presses, sprite clicks, and backdrop changes
Create an interactive program where different keys trigger different sprite actions or sounds
Use broadcast messages to make sprites communicate and coordinate their actions

sub_topics.name: Timing and Synchronization
sub_topics.short_description: Controlling timing with wait blocks and synchronizing multiple sprites.
example_tasks: Add wait blocks to control the pace of animations and create pauses between actions
Synchronize two sprites to perform a choreographed sequence using broadcasts and wait blocks
Create a countdown timer using wait blocks and changing number displays

sub_topics.name: Loops and Iteration
sub_topics.short_description: Using repeat, forever, and conditional loops to execute code multiple times.

sub_topics.name: Repeat Loops
sub_topics.short_description: Using repeat blocks to execute code a specific number of times.
example_tasks: Create a square by using a repeat 4 block that moves forward and turns 90 degrees
Program a sprite to bounce around the screen a specific number of times using repeat loops
Use nested repeat loops to create patterns or grids of shapes

sub_topics.name: Forever Loops
sub_topics.short_description: Creating continuous behaviors that run throughout the program.
example_tasks: Make a sprite continuously follow the mouse pointer using a forever loop with go to mouse-pointer blocks
Create scrolling backgrounds or moving obstacles that loop continuously
Program a sprite to constantly check for collisions or boundary conditions in a forever loop

sub_topics.name: Conditional Loops (Repeat Until)
sub_topics.short_description: Repeating code until a specific condition becomes true.
example_tasks: Use repeat until blocks to make a sprite move until it reaches a specific position or touches another sprite
Create a game where an action repeats until a score reaches a target value
Program a searching behavior where a sprite moves randomly until it finds another sprite or color

sub_topics.name: Conditionals and Decision Making
sub_topics.short_description: Using if and if-else blocks to make decisions based on conditions.

sub_topics.name: If Statements
sub_topics.short_description: Executing code only when a condition is true.
example_tasks: Program a sprite to change costume or play a sound if it touches the edge or another sprite
Create an interactive program where clicking on sprites triggers different actions using if touching mouse-pointer
Use if statements to check sensing conditions like key pressed, answer to questions, or color detection

sub_topics.name: If-Else Statements
sub_topics.short_description: Choosing between two different actions based on a condition.
example_tasks: Create a game where a sprite says 'Correct!' or 'Try again' based on whether the user's answer matches the right answer
Program a character to move right if the right arrow is pressed, else move left if the left arrow is pressed
Make a sprite bounce off edges by checking if it's touching the edge and changing direction accordingly

sub_topics.name: Nested Conditionals
sub_topics.short_description: Placing conditionals inside other conditionals for complex decision trees.
example_tasks: Create a multi-choice quiz where nested if-else blocks check multiple possible answers
Program game logic with nested conditionals like checking if touching an enemy AND if the player has a shield
Build a decision tree for classifying objects based on multiple characteristics using nested if statements

sub_topics.name: Boolean Operators and Complex Conditions
sub_topics.short_description: Combining conditions using AND, OR, and NOT operators.
example_tasks: Use AND blocks to create conditions that require multiple things to be true simultaneously
Use OR blocks to trigger actions when any of several conditions is true
Combine NOT operators to reverse conditions or check for the absence of something

sub_topics.name: Variables and Lists in Scratch
sub_topics.short_description: Creating and using variables to store data and lists to store collections of items.

sub_topics.name: Creating and Using Variables
sub_topics.short_description: Making variables to store scores, names, or other changing data.
example_tasks: Create a score variable and program it to increase when the player catches objects or completes challenges
Use a timer variable that counts up or down during gameplay
Store user input in a variable and use it later in the program for personalization

sub_topics.name: Variable Scope (For All Sprites vs For This Sprite Only)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding when variables should be global or sprite-specific.
example_tasks: Create global variables that all sprites can access like a game score or level number
Create sprite-specific variables for properties unique to each sprite like health or speed
Debug problems caused by using the wrong variable scope and fix by changing to appropriate scope

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Lists
sub_topics.short_description: Creating lists to store multiple values and accessing list items.
example_tasks: Create a list to store quiz questions or vocabulary words and access them one at a time
Add items to a list during program execution like collecting objects or recording high scores
Use list operations like getting item number, length of list, and checking if list contains an item

sub_topics.name: Iterating Through Lists
sub_topics.short_description: Using loops to process all items in a list.
example_tasks: Loop through a list of questions displaying each one and checking the user's answer
Process all items in a list to find the maximum value, sum all values, or search for a specific item
Create a program that randomly selects items from a list without repeating using list manipulation

sub_topics.name: Interactive Projects and Games
sub_topics.short_description: Combining programming concepts to create games, stories, and interactive experiences.

sub_topics.name: Game Design Fundamentals
sub_topics.short_description: Planning and implementing basic game mechanics like goals, scoring, and levels.
example_tasks: Design a simple collection game where the player moves a sprite to collect objects while avoiding obstacles
Create a quiz game with multiple questions, score tracking, and feedback for correct and incorrect answers
Build a platformer-style game with jumping, collision detection, and level completion

sub_topics.name: User Input and Interaction
sub_topics.short_description: Creating programs that respond to keyboard, mouse, and voice input.
example_tasks: Create a drawing program that follows the mouse and changes pen color based on key presses
Program character movement controlled by arrow keys or WASD with smooth acceleration and stopping
Use the ask block to get text input from users and respond appropriately based on their answers

sub_topics.name: Sound and Animation
sub_topics.short_description: Adding sound effects, music, and animations to enhance projects.
example_tasks: Add background music and sound effects that play during specific game events or user actions
Create smooth sprite animations using costume changes, glide blocks, and graphic effects
Use sound sensors or timing to create music visualization or rhythm-based interactions

sub_topics.name: Clones and Advanced Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Using clones to create multiple instances of sprites dynamically.
example_tasks: Create clones of sprites to generate multiple enemies, projectiles, or collectible items during gameplay
Program clones to have individual behaviors while being created and deleted dynamically
Build a particle system using clones to create effects like explosions, rain, or stars

name: Python Programming Fundamentals
short_description: Students learn Python syntax, work with variables and data types, use input/output functions, and write simple programs using a text-based programming language.

sub_topics.name: Python Setup and Development Environment
sub_topics.short_description: Setting up Python, understanding the interpreter, using IDEs, and writing first programs.

sub_topics.name: Installing and Running Python
sub_topics.short_description: Installing Python, using IDLE or other IDEs, and running Python programs.
example_tasks: Install Python on your computer and verify the installation by checking the version in the command line using python --version
Write and run your first Python program that prints 'Hello, World!' using IDLE or another Python IDE
Compare running Python programs in interactive mode (typing commands one at a time) versus script mode (writing and executing files)

sub_topics.name: Python Development Environments
sub_topics.short_description: Using different Python IDEs and online coding platforms for development.
example_tasks: Explore different Python IDEs (IDLE, PyCharm, VS Code, Thonny) and identify features like syntax highlighting, error detection, and debugging tools
Use an online Python platform like Replit or Trinket to write and run Python code without local installation
Practice using the interactive Python shell for testing code snippets before adding them to programs

sub_topics.name: Python Syntax Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Python syntax rules including indentation, comments, and case sensitivity.
example_tasks: Write Python programs demonstrating proper indentation and explain why indentation is critical in Python (unlike some other languages)
Add single-line comments using # and multi-line comments using triple quotes to explain what code does
Debug programs with syntax errors caused by incorrect indentation, missing colons, or typos and fix them

sub_topics.name: Python Variables and Data Types
sub_topics.short_description: Working with variables, understanding Python data types, and performing type conversions.

sub_topics.name: Variable Assignment and Naming
sub_topics.short_description: Creating variables, following naming conventions, and understanding variable assignment.
example_tasks: Create variables to store different types of information like name = 'Alex', age = 13, height = 5.2 following Python naming conventions
Evaluate variable names for validity (must start with letter or underscore, no spaces, no reserved words) and correct invalid names
Practice assigning new values to variables and understand that variables can change throughout program execution

sub_topics.name: Python Data Types
sub_topics.short_description: Working with integers, floats, strings, and booleans in Python.
example_tasks: Use the type() function to determine the data type of different values and variables
Create variables of each type: int (42), float (3.14), str ('hello'), bool (True) and demonstrate their different uses
Explain when to use each data type based on what kind of information needs to be stored

sub_topics.name: Type Conversion and Casting
sub_topics.short_description: Converting between data types using int(), float(), str(), and bool() functions.
example_tasks: Convert user input strings to integers or floats using int() and float() to perform mathematical calculations
Convert numbers to strings using str() to concatenate them with text in output messages
Debug common type errors like trying to add strings and numbers, and fix them with appropriate type conversion

sub_topics.name: String Operations in Python
sub_topics.short_description: Manipulating strings using concatenation, indexing, slicing, and string methods.
example_tasks: Concatenate strings using the + operator and repeat strings using * to build messages and patterns
Access individual characters in strings using indexing (string[0]) and extract substrings using slicing (string[1:4])
Use string methods like .upper(), .lower(), .strip(), .replace(), and .split() to manipulate text

sub_topics.name: Input and Output in Python
sub_topics.short_description: Getting user input, displaying output, and formatting text for readable programs.

sub_topics.name: Print Function and Output
sub_topics.short_description: Using print() to display text, variables, and formatted output.
example_tasks: Use print() to display text, variables, and combinations of both using commas or concatenation
Print multiple items on the same line using print() parameters like sep and end
Format output using escape sequences like \n (newline) and \t (tab) for better readability

sub_topics.name: Input Function and User Input
sub_topics.short_description: Using input() to get data from users and storing it in variables.
example_tasks: Create a program that asks for the user's name using input() and stores it in a variable, then greets them by name
Get multiple pieces of information from users with separate input() calls and use them in calculations or output
Convert input() results (which are always strings) to numbers when needed for mathematical operations

sub_topics.name: String Formatting
sub_topics.short_description: Formatting output using f-strings, .format(), and string concatenation.
example_tasks: Use f-strings to embed variables directly in strings like f'Hello, {name}! You are {age} years old.'
Format numbers in output to show specific decimal places like f'Price: ${price:.2f}'
Create formatted tables or aligned output using string formatting techniques

sub_topics.name: Python Operators and Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Using arithmetic, comparison, logical, and assignment operators in Python programs.

sub_topics.name: Arithmetic Operators
sub_topics.short_description: Performing calculations using +, -, *, /, //, %, and ** operators.
example_tasks: Write expressions using basic arithmetic operators and follow order of operations (PEMDAS) with parentheses for grouping
Use integer division (//) to get whole number results and modulus (%) to find remainders
Calculate exponents using the ** operator like 2**3 for 2 cubed

sub_topics.name: Comparison Operators
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing values using ==, !=, <, >, <=, >= operators.
example_tasks: Write comparison expressions that evaluate to True or False and test them with different values
Use comparison operators to create conditions for decision-making in programs
Understand the difference between = (assignment) and == (comparison) and avoid common mistakes

sub_topics.name: Logical Operators
sub_topics.short_description: Combining conditions using and, or, and not operators.
example_tasks: Create compound conditions using and (both must be true), or (at least one must be true), and not (reverses truth value)
Write programs that check multiple conditions like 'if age >= 13 and age <= 19' to identify teenagers
Use logical operators to simplify complex decision logic and make code more readable

sub_topics.name: Assignment and Compound Operators
sub_topics.short_description: Using =, +=, -=, *=, /= and other compound assignment operators.
example_tasks: Use compound assignment operators like score += 10 as shorthand for score = score + 10
Apply +=, -=, *=, /= operators to update variables efficiently in loops and calculations
Understand that assignment operators modify variables in place and return the new value

sub_topics.name: Control Structures in Python
sub_topics.short_description: Using if statements, loops, and control flow to create programs that make decisions and repeat actions.

sub_topics.name: If, Elif, and Else Statements
sub_topics.short_description: Making decisions in programs using conditional statements.
example_tasks: Write if statements that execute code only when conditions are true, using proper indentation
Create if-elif-else chains to handle multiple mutually exclusive conditions like grade ranges
Build a simple decision-making program like a number guessing game or grade calculator using conditionals

sub_topics.name: Nested Conditionals
sub_topics.short_description: Placing if statements inside other if statements for complex logic.
example_tasks: Create nested if statements to check multiple levels of conditions like checking if a number is positive, then if it's even
Build decision trees for classification problems using nested conditionals
Refactor complex nested conditionals using logical operators to make code more readable

sub_topics.name: While Loops
sub_topics.short_description: Repeating code while a condition remains true.
example_tasks: Create while loops that repeat code until a condition becomes false, like counting from 1 to 10
Build input validation loops that keep asking for input until the user provides valid data
Use while loops with counters, updating the counter inside the loop to avoid infinite loops

sub_topics.name: For Loops and Range
sub_topics.short_description: Repeating code a specific number of times using for loops and range().
example_tasks: Use for loops with range() to repeat actions a specific number of times like for i in range(10)
Loop through sequences of numbers using range(start, stop, step) for different counting patterns
Create multiplication tables, patterns, or repetitive calculations using for loops

sub_topics.name: Loop Control (Break and Continue)
sub_topics.short_description: Controlling loop execution using break and continue statements.
example_tasks: Use break to exit a loop early when a specific condition is met, like finding a target value
Use continue to skip the rest of the current iteration and move to the next one
Create a number guessing game where break exits the loop when the correct number is guessed

name: JavaScript Basics
short_description: Students learn JavaScript syntax, manipulate web page elements, respond to user events, and create interactive web experiences using client-side scripting.

sub_topics.name: Introduction to JavaScript
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding what JavaScript is, where it runs, and how to include it in web pages.

sub_topics.name: JavaScript Purpose and Uses
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding why JavaScript is essential for modern web development and interactive websites.
example_tasks: Research and list examples of website features that require JavaScript like form validation, interactive maps, and dynamic content
Compare static HTML pages to JavaScript-enhanced pages by examining the difference in interactivity and user experience
Explore websites with JavaScript disabled and observe what functionality is lost

sub_topics.name: Including JavaScript in HTML
sub_topics.short_description: Adding JavaScript to web pages using script tags, inline code, and external files.
example_tasks: Create an HTML page with inline JavaScript using <script> tags in the head or body sections
Write JavaScript in an external .js file and link it to an HTML page using <script src='script.js'>
Compare inline, internal, and external JavaScript placement and understand best practices for organization

sub_topics.name: Browser Console and Debugging
sub_topics.short_description: Using browser developer tools to test JavaScript and view console output.
example_tasks: Open browser developer tools (F12) and use the console to test JavaScript commands interactively
Use console.log() to display messages, variable values, and debug information in the browser console
View and fix JavaScript errors that appear in the console with line numbers and error descriptions

sub_topics.name: JavaScript Syntax and Variables
sub_topics.short_description: Learning JavaScript syntax rules, variable declaration, and basic data types.

sub_topics.name: JavaScript Syntax Fundamentals
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding JavaScript syntax including semicolons, case sensitivity, and comments.
example_tasks: Write JavaScript code following proper syntax including semicolons at the end of statements and proper spacing
Add single-line (//) and multi-line (/* */) comments to explain JavaScript code
Debug syntax errors caused by missing semicolons, incorrect capitalization, or mismatched brackets

sub_topics.name: Variable Declaration (var, let, const)
sub_topics.short_description: Declaring variables using var, let, and const with appropriate scope and mutability.
example_tasks: Declare variables using let for values that will change and const for values that remain constant
Understand the difference between var (function scope) and let (block scope) through examples
Practice declaring and initializing variables with descriptive names following camelCase convention

sub_topics.name: JavaScript Data Types
sub_topics.short_description: Working with numbers, strings, booleans, null, and undefined in JavaScript.
example_tasks: Create variables of different types: number (42, 3.14), string ('hello', "world"), boolean (true, false)
Use typeof operator to check the data type of variables and values
Understand special values like null (intentional absence) and undefined (variable declared but not assigned)

sub_topics.name: Type Coercion and Conversion
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding automatic type conversion and explicit type casting in JavaScript.
example_tasks: Observe type coercion when mixing different types in operations like '5' + 3 resulting in '53'
Use explicit conversion functions like Number(), String(), parseInt(), and parseFloat()
Debug unexpected results caused by type coercion and fix with appropriate conversions

sub_topics.name: JavaScript Operators and Expressions
sub_topics.short_description: Using operators to perform calculations, comparisons, and logical operations in JavaScript.

sub_topics.name: Arithmetic Operators in JavaScript
sub_topics.short_description: Performing mathematical calculations using JavaScript operators.
example_tasks: Use arithmetic operators (+, -, *, /, %, **) to perform calculations and understand operator precedence
Apply increment (++) and decrement (--) operators to modify variables
Create calculators or mathematical programs using arithmetic operators and displaying results on web pages

sub_topics.name: Comparison and Logical Operators
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing values and creating complex conditions using JavaScript operators.
example_tasks: Use comparison operators (==, ===, !=, !==, <, >, <=, >=) understanding the difference between == (loose) and === (strict) equality
Combine conditions using logical operators (&&, ||, !) to create complex boolean expressions
Write validation logic using comparison and logical operators to check user input

sub_topics.name: String Manipulation in JavaScript
sub_topics.short_description: Working with strings using concatenation, template literals, and string methods.
example_tasks: Concatenate strings using + operator and template literals using backticks `Hello ${name}`
Use string methods like .length, .toUpperCase(), .toLowerCase(), .substring(), .indexOf(), .split()
Create dynamic text content by combining variables and strings for display on web pages

sub_topics.name: DOM Manipulation
sub_topics.short_description: Accessing and modifying HTML elements using JavaScript to create dynamic web pages.

sub_topics.name: Selecting HTML Elements
sub_topics.short_description: Using JavaScript to find and select elements from the HTML document.
example_tasks: Use document.getElementById() to select elements by their id attribute
Select elements using document.querySelector() and document.querySelectorAll() with CSS selectors
Store element references in variables to manipulate them throughout the program

sub_topics.name: Changing Element Content and Attributes
sub_topics.short_description: Modifying text, HTML, and attributes of elements using JavaScript.
example_tasks: Change text content of elements using .textContent or .innerHTML properties
Modify element attributes like src, href, alt using .setAttribute() or direct property access
Create an interactive page where clicking buttons changes the text or images displayed

sub_topics.name: Styling Elements with JavaScript
sub_topics.short_description: Changing CSS properties and classes of elements dynamically.
example_tasks: Modify inline styles using element.style.property like element.style.color = 'blue'
Add, remove, or toggle CSS classes using .classList.add(), .classList.remove(), and .classList.toggle()
Create interactive styling changes like hover effects, theme switchers, or show/hide functionality

sub_topics.name: Creating and Removing Elements
sub_topics.short_description: Dynamically creating new HTML elements and removing existing ones with JavaScript.
example_tasks: Create new elements using document.createElement() and add them to the page with .appendChild() or .insertBefore()
Remove elements from the page using .removeChild() or .remove()
Build a to-do list where items can be added and removed dynamically using JavaScript

sub_topics.name: JavaScript Events and Interactivity
sub_topics.short_description: Responding to user actions like clicks, keyboard input, and mouse movements to create interactive experiences.

sub_topics.name: Event Listeners
sub_topics.short_description: Setting up event listeners to respond when specific events occur.
example_tasks: Add click event listeners to buttons using .addEventListener('click', function) to execute code when clicked
Create event handler functions that run when events fire, accessing the event object for details
Remove event listeners using .removeEventListener() when they're no longer needed

sub_topics.name: Mouse Events
sub_topics.short_description: Responding to mouse clicks, movements, and hover actions.
example_tasks: Handle different mouse events like click, dblclick, mouseenter, mouseleave, and mousemove
Create interactive elements that change appearance when the mouse hovers over them
Build a simple drawing program that tracks mouse movement and position

sub_topics.name: Keyboard Events
sub_topics.short_description: Responding to keyboard input and key presses.
example_tasks: Listen for keydown, keyup, and keypress events and identify which key was pressed using event.key or event.code
Create keyboard-controlled interactions like moving elements with arrow keys
Build form validation that provides real-time feedback as users type

sub_topics.name: Form Events and Validation
sub_topics.short_description: Handling form submissions and validating user input with JavaScript.
example_tasks: Prevent form submission using event.preventDefault() to validate input before sending
Validate form fields checking for empty values, correct formats (email, phone), and required fields
Display error messages next to form fields when validation fails and clear them when corrected

sub_topics.name: Control Flow in JavaScript
sub_topics.short_description: Using conditionals and loops to control program flow in JavaScript.

sub_topics.name: If-Else Statements in JavaScript
sub_topics.short_description: Making decisions using if, else if, and else statements.
example_tasks: Write if-else statements to make decisions based on conditions like user input or element states
Create multiple condition checks using else if chains for different scenarios
Use ternary operators (condition ? value1 : value2) for simple conditional assignments

sub_topics.name: Switch Statements
sub_topics.short_description: Handling multiple cases efficiently using switch statements.
example_tasks: Create switch statements to handle multiple specific values more cleanly than long if-else chains
Use break statements to prevent fall-through between cases
Implement a simple calculator or menu system using switch statements for different operations

sub_topics.name: Loops in JavaScript
sub_topics.short_description: Repeating code using for, while, and do-while loops.
example_tasks: Create for loops to repeat actions a specific number of times using counter variables
Use while loops to repeat code while conditions are true, like processing user input until valid
Loop through arrays using for loops or for...of loops to process each element

name: Data Structures and Algorithms
short_description: Students learn to organize data using lists, arrays, dictionaries, and sets, and implement common algorithms for sorting and searching.

sub_topics.name: Lists and Arrays
sub_topics.short_description: Storing and manipulating collections of data using ordered sequences.

sub_topics.name: Creating and Accessing Lists/Arrays
sub_topics.short_description: Creating lists, accessing elements by index, and understanding zero-based indexing.
example_tasks: Create lists/arrays containing multiple values like scores = [85, 92, 78, 95] and access individual elements using indices
Use negative indexing to access elements from the end of the list like scores[-1] for the last element
Practice accessing elements at specific positions and understand IndexError when accessing out-of-bounds indices

sub_topics.name: Modifying Lists/Arrays
sub_topics.short_description: Adding, removing, and changing elements in lists and arrays.
example_tasks: Add elements to lists using .append() (end), .insert() (specific position), or concatenation with +
Remove elements using .remove() (by value), .pop() (by index), or del statement
Modify existing elements by assigning new values to specific indices like scores[2] = 88

sub_topics.name: List Operations and Methods
sub_topics.short_description: Using built-in methods and operations to work with lists efficiently.
example_tasks: Find list length using len(), check if items exist using 'in' operator, and concatenate lists with +
Use list methods like .sort(), .reverse(), .count(), and .index() to manipulate and query lists
Create a program that manages a collection of items (shopping list, inventory) using list operations

sub_topics.name: Iterating Through Lists
sub_topics.short_description: Using loops to process each element in a list or array.
example_tasks: Loop through list elements using for item in list to process each element
Use enumerate() to get both index and value when iterating like for i, value in enumerate(list)
Calculate totals, averages, or find maximum/minimum values by iterating through numeric lists

sub_topics.name: List Comprehensions
sub_topics.short_description: Creating new lists from existing ones using concise comprehension syntax.
example_tasks: Create new lists using comprehensions like squares = [x**2 for x in range(10)]
Filter lists using conditions in comprehensions like evens = [x for x in numbers if x % 2 == 0]
Transform list data using comprehensions instead of traditional loops for more concise code

sub_topics.name: Dictionaries and Objects
sub_topics.short_description: Storing data as key-value pairs for efficient lookup and organization.

sub_topics.name: Creating and Accessing Dictionaries
sub_topics.short_description: Creating dictionaries with key-value pairs and accessing values by key.
example_tasks: Create dictionaries using curly braces like student = {'name': 'Alex', 'age': 13, 'grade': 8}
Access dictionary values using keys like student['name'] or .get() method
Understand KeyError when accessing non-existent keys and use .get() with defaults to avoid errors

sub_topics.name: Modifying Dictionaries
sub_topics.short_description: Adding, updating, and removing key-value pairs in dictionaries.
example_tasks: Add new key-value pairs by assigning to new keys like student['school'] = 'Lincoln Middle School'
Update existing values by reassigning like student['grade'] = 9
Remove entries using del statement or .pop() method

sub_topics.name: Dictionary Methods and Operations
sub_topics.short_description: Using dictionary methods to work with keys, values, and items.
example_tasks: Use .keys() to get all keys, .values() to get all values, and .items() to get key-value pairs
Check if keys exist using 'in' operator like if 'name' in student
Iterate through dictionaries using for key in dict or for key, value in dict.items()

sub_topics.name: Nested Data Structures
sub_topics.short_description: Working with lists inside dictionaries or dictionaries inside lists.
example_tasks: Create nested structures like a list of dictionaries to represent multiple students with their information
Access nested data using multiple brackets or keys like students[0]['name']
Build a contact list, gradebook, or inventory system using nested data structures

sub_topics.name: Searching Algorithms
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing algorithms to find specific elements in data collections.

sub_topics.name: Linear Search
sub_topics.short_description: Searching through lists sequentially from beginning to end.
example_tasks: Implement linear search that checks each element in order until finding the target or reaching the end
Count how many comparisons linear search requires for lists of different sizes
Understand when linear search is appropriate (unsorted data, small lists) versus when other approaches are better

sub_topics.name: Binary Search
sub_topics.short_description: Efficiently searching sorted lists by repeatedly dividing the search space in half.
example_tasks: Implement binary search that compares the target to the middle element and narrows the search to half the list
Compare the efficiency of binary search versus linear search for large sorted lists
Understand that binary search requires sorted data and trace through the algorithm with examples

sub_topics.name: Search Algorithm Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Applying search algorithms to solve real-world problems.
example_tasks: Create a program that searches for student records by name or ID using appropriate search algorithms
Implement autocomplete functionality that searches for matching entries as users type
Compare search performance by measuring time or counting operations for different algorithms and data sizes

sub_topics.name: Sorting Algorithms
sub_topics.short_description: Implementing algorithms to arrange data in order.

sub_topics.name: Bubble Sort
sub_topics.short_description: Sorting by repeatedly swapping adjacent elements that are out of order.
example_tasks: Implement bubble sort that compares adjacent elements and swaps them if they're in wrong order, repeating until sorted
Visualize bubble sort by printing the list after each pass to see how elements "bubble" to their positions
Count the number of swaps and comparisons bubble sort makes for different list sizes

sub_topics.name: Selection Sort
sub_topics.short_description: Sorting by repeatedly finding the minimum element and placing it in order.
example_tasks: Implement selection sort that finds the smallest unsorted element and swaps it to the correct position
Trace through selection sort step-by-step showing how the sorted portion grows
Compare selection sort to bubble sort in terms of swaps required and overall efficiency

sub_topics.name: Insertion Sort
sub_topics.short_description: Sorting by building a sorted list one element at a time by inserting elements in the correct position.
example_tasks: Implement insertion sort that takes each element and inserts it into its correct position in the sorted portion
Understand how insertion sort works similarly to sorting playing cards in your hand
Analyze when insertion sort performs well (nearly sorted data) versus poorly (reverse-sorted data)

sub_topics.name: Comparing Sorting Algorithms
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing and comparing the efficiency of different sorting algorithms.
example_tasks: Compare the time different sorting algorithms take to sort the same data
Identify best-case, average-case, and worst-case scenarios for different sorting algorithms
Research and use built-in sorting functions (.sort(), sorted()) and compare to manual implementations

name: Debugging and Testing
short_description: Students learn to identify and fix errors in code, use debugging strategies and tools, write test cases, and develop systematic problem-solving approaches.

sub_topics.name: Types of Programming Errors
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding syntax errors, runtime errors, and logic errors and how to identify each type.

sub_topics.name: Syntax Errors
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying and fixing errors in code structure and grammar that prevent programs from running.
example_tasks: Identify common syntax errors like missing colons, unmatched parentheses, incorrect indentation, and misspelled keywords
Read error messages to understand what's wrong and where the error occurs (line numbers)
Practice fixing syntax errors in broken code samples by carefully checking code structure

sub_topics.name: Runtime Errors
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding errors that occur during program execution like division by zero or type errors.
example_tasks: Identify runtime errors such as ZeroDivisionError, TypeError, NameError, and IndexError
Add error handling using try-except blocks to catch and handle runtime errors gracefully
Debug programs that crash during execution by examining the error traceback and identifying the problematic line

sub_topics.name: Logic Errors
sub_topics.short_description: Finding errors where code runs without crashing but produces incorrect results.
example_tasks: Identify logic errors by comparing actual program output to expected output and finding discrepancies
Trace through code step-by-step to find where logic deviates from the intended algorithm
Fix off-by-one errors, incorrect conditionals, and wrong formulas that cause incorrect behavior

sub_topics.name: Debugging Strategies and Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Applying systematic approaches to find and fix bugs in programs.

sub_topics.name: Print Statement Debugging
sub_topics.short_description: Using print statements to display variable values and track program flow.
example_tasks: Add print statements at key points in code to display variable values and verify they contain expected data
Trace program execution by printing messages showing which parts of code are executing
Use print statements to narrow down where errors occur by printing before and after suspicious code sections

sub_topics.name: Using Debugger Tools
sub_topics.short_description: Using IDE debuggers to set breakpoints, step through code, and inspect variables.
example_tasks: Set breakpoints in code to pause execution at specific lines and examine program state
Step through code line-by-line using step over, step into, and step out controls
Watch variables and expressions to see how values change during program execution

sub_topics.name: Explaining Code and Rubber Duck Debugging
sub_topics.short_description: Finding bugs by explaining code aloud or to others.
example_tasks: Practice rubber duck debugging by explaining code line-by-line to find errors through explanation
Work in pairs doing code reviews where one person explains their code to another
Document what code is supposed to do versus what it actually does to identify logic errors

sub_topics.name: Systematic Debugging Process
sub_topics.short_description: Following a methodical approach to isolate and fix bugs.
example_tasks: Apply the debugging process: reproduce the bug, isolate the problem, identify the cause, fix it, and test the fix
Use binary search debugging by testing sections of code to narrow down where bugs occur
Document bugs including symptoms, reproduction steps, cause identified, and solution applied

sub_topics.name: Testing and Test Cases
sub_topics.short_description: Writing and running test cases to verify that programs work correctly.

sub_topics.name: Designing Test Cases
sub_topics.short_description: Creating comprehensive tests that cover different scenarios and edge cases.
example_tasks: Design test cases for programs including normal inputs, edge cases (empty, maximum, minimum), and invalid inputs
Create a test plan listing inputs to try and expected outputs for each
Test boundary conditions like the first and last elements of lists or maximum/minimum values

sub_topics.name: Manual Testing
sub_topics.short_description: Testing programs manually by running them with different inputs and verifying outputs.
example_tasks: Manually test programs with a variety of inputs recording actual versus expected results
Create test logs documenting which tests passed, which failed, and what errors occurred
Perform regression testing to ensure that fixing one bug didn't create new bugs elsewhere

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Automated Testing
sub_topics.short_description: Writing simple automated tests that check if functions return expected values.
example_tasks: Write assertions that check if function outputs match expected values like assert add(2, 3) == 5
Create test functions that call program functions with various inputs and report pass/fail
Understand the benefits of automated tests that can be run repeatedly as code changes

sub_topics.name: Code Review and Improvement
sub_topics.short_description: Reviewing code for errors, readability, and efficiency, and making improvements.

sub_topics.name: Peer Code Review
sub_topics.short_description: Reviewing others' code and having others review yours to find bugs and improve quality.
example_tasks: Review a peer's code checking for errors, unclear variable names, missing comments, and logic issues
Provide constructive feedback focusing on specific improvements rather than general criticism
Accept feedback on your own code and make revisions based on peer suggestions

sub_topics.name: Code Readability and Style
sub_topics.short_description: Writing code that is easy to read and understand using clear naming and formatting.
example_tasks: Refactor code to use descriptive variable and function names that explain their purpose
Add comments explaining complex sections but avoid over-commenting obvious code
Follow consistent indentation, spacing, and naming conventions throughout programs

sub_topics.name: Code Refactoring
sub_topics.short_description: Improving code structure and efficiency without changing functionality.
example_tasks: Identify and eliminate repeated code by creating functions for common operations
Simplify complex conditionals using logical operators or reorganizing logic
Optimize code by removing unnecessary operations, using better algorithms, or simplifying logic

name: Problem Solving with Code
short_description: Students apply computational thinking and programming skills to solve real-world problems through decomposition, planning, implementation, and iteration.

sub_topics.name: Problem Analysis and Planning
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding problems thoroughly and planning solutions before coding.

sub_topics.name: Understanding Problem Requirements
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying what a program needs to do including inputs, outputs, and constraints.
example_tasks: Read problem descriptions carefully and list what inputs the program needs and what outputs it should produce
Identify constraints and requirements like data validation rules, performance needs, or user interface elements
Ask clarifying questions to fully understand ambiguous or incomplete problem specifications

sub_topics.name: Planning Solutions
sub_topics.short_description: Creating plans and designs before writing code.
