example_tasks: Write pseudocode or create flowcharts to plan the algorithm before implementing in a programming language
Break complex problems into smaller sub-problems and plan how to solve each part
Sketch user interfaces or program flows to visualize how the program will work

sub_topics.name: Selecting Appropriate Algorithms
sub_topics.short_description: Choosing the right approach or algorithm for specific problems.
example_tasks: Evaluate different possible algorithms for a problem and choose based on efficiency and simplicity
Recognize common problem patterns like searching, sorting, counting, or accumulating and apply standard approaches
Compare trade-offs between different solutions considering time, memory, and code complexity

sub_topics.name: Incremental Development
sub_topics.short_description: Building programs piece by piece, testing each part before adding more functionality.

sub_topics.name: Starting with Simple Cases
sub_topics.short_description: Beginning with basic functionality and building up to full features.
example_tasks: Create a minimal working version of a program that handles the simplest case before adding complexity
Test basic functionality before adding error handling, validation, or advanced features
Build programs iteratively adding one feature at a time rather than trying to write everything at once

sub_topics.name: Testing During Development
sub_topics.short_description: Testing each component as it's built to catch errors early.
example_tasks: Test each function or section of code immediately after writing it to verify correctness
Run programs frequently during development to catch bugs as soon as they're introduced
Use test inputs at each stage to verify that new code works correctly before proceeding

sub_topics.name: Iteration and Refinement
sub_topics.short_description: Improving programs through multiple rounds of development and testing.
example_tasks: Create an initial working version then iteratively add features, fix bugs, and improve efficiency
Gather feedback from users or testers and incorporate improvements in subsequent versions
Refactor code as programs grow to keep them maintainable and understandable

sub_topics.name: Programming Project Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Applying problem-solving skills to complete projects that integrate multiple concepts.

sub_topics.name: Games and Simulations
sub_topics.short_description: Creating interactive games and simulations using programming concepts.
example_tasks: Build a number guessing game with hints, score tracking, and limited attempts using loops and conditionals
Create a text-based adventure game with multiple rooms, items, and choices using data structures and functions
Develop a simulation like population growth, ecosystem dynamics, or economic models using algorithms and data analysis

sub_topics.name: Data Processing and Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Processing and analyzing data from files or user input to extract insights.
example_tasks: Read data from files, process it (calculate averages, find patterns, filter results), and output summaries
Create programs that analyze text to count words, find most common terms, or check reading level
Process student grade data to calculate averages, identify high/low performers, and generate reports

sub_topics.name: Utilities and Tools
sub_topics.short_description: Creating practical programs that perform useful tasks or automate work.
example_tasks: Build a password strength checker that analyzes passwords and provides feedback on security
Create a unit converter that converts between different measurement systems with user-friendly interface
Develop a calculator with advanced features like memory, history, and multiple operations

sub_topics.name: Creative Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Using programming for artistic and creative expression.
example_tasks: Generate ASCII art or text-based images using loops and character patterns
Create programs that generate random stories, poems, or creative text using templates and word lists
Build music or rhythm programs that play sequences, respond to input, or generate compositions

name: HTML Fundamentals
short_description: Students learn to create web page structure using HTML elements, tags, attributes, and semantic markup to build well-organized, accessible websites.

sub_topics.name: HTML Basics and Document Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding HTML purpose, document structure, and basic syntax for creating web pages.

sub_topics.name: Introduction to HTML
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding what HTML is, its role in web development, and how browsers interpret it.
example_tasks: Explain what HTML stands for (HyperText Markup Language) and its purpose in creating web page structure
View the HTML source code of websites using browser developer tools to see how pages are constructed
Compare HTML (structure), CSS (style), and JavaScript (behavior) to understand the role of each in web development

sub_topics.name: HTML Document Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Creating valid HTML documents with proper structure including DOCTYPE, html, head, and body tags.
example_tasks: Create a basic HTML document with required elements: <!DOCTYPE html>, <html>, <head>, <title>, and <body>
Understand the purpose of each structural element: DOCTYPE declares version, head contains metadata, body contains visible content
Validate HTML documents using W3C validator to ensure proper structure and fix any errors

sub_topics.name: HTML Syntax and Tags
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding tag structure, opening/closing tags, self-closing tags, and nesting.
example_tasks:
Write HTML elements with proper syntax including opening tags

, closing tags

, and self-closing tags
Practice proper nesting of elements ensuring tags are closed in reverse order of opening
Identify and fix common HTML syntax errors like unclosed tags, improper nesting, or missing required attributes

sub_topics.name: HTML Comments
sub_topics.short_description: Adding comments to HTML documents to explain code without affecting display.
example_tasks: Add HTML comments using <!-- comment text --> to document code sections or leave notes
Use comments to temporarily disable sections of HTML during development or testing
Practice adding meaningful comments that explain complex structures or leave reminders for future edits

sub_topics.name: Text Content and Formatting
sub_topics.short_description: Using HTML elements to structure and format text including headings, paragraphs, lists, and emphasis.

sub_topics.name: Headings and Paragraphs
sub_topics.short_description: Creating document hierarchy with heading levels and organizing text into paragraphs.
example_tasks: Use heading tags <h1> through <h6> to create document hierarchy with h1 as the main title and h2-h6 as subheadings

Organize text content using

paragraph tags, understanding that paragraphs create vertical spacing automatically
Create a properly structured article with a main heading, subheadings, and multiple paragraphs of content

sub_topics.name: Text Formatting Elements
sub_topics.short_description: Applying emphasis, importance, and other formatting to text within content.
example_tasks: Use <strong> for important text (bold) and <em> for emphasized text (italic) with semantic meaning
Apply additional formatting tags like <mark> for highlighting, <small> for fine print, <sub> and <sup> for subscript/superscript
Understand the difference between semantic tags (strong, em) and presentational tags (b, i) and prefer semantic markup

sub_topics.name: Ordered and Unordered Lists
sub_topics.short_description: Creating lists using ul, ol, and li elements for organizing related items.
example_tasks: Create unordered lists using <ul> and <li> tags for bullet-point lists of items without specific order
Create ordered lists using <ol> and <li> tags for numbered lists showing sequential steps or ranked items
Create nested lists by placing ul or ol elements inside li elements for sub-lists and hierarchical information

sub_topics.name: Special Text Elements
sub_topics.short_description: Using elements for quotations, code, and other special text types.
example_tasks: Display inline code using <code> tags and code blocks using <pre> and <code> together to preserve formatting
Add quotations using <blockquote> for long quotes and <q> for short inline quotes with proper attribution
Use <abbr> with title attribute for abbreviations and <time> for dates and times with semantic meaning

sub_topics.name: Links and Navigation
sub_topics.short_description: Creating hyperlinks to connect pages and resources, building navigation systems.

sub_topics.name: Creating Hyperlinks
sub_topics.short_description: Using anchor tags to create links to other pages, websites, and resources.
example_tasks: Create links using link text to connect to other web pages or external websites
Understand absolute URLs (https://example.com) versus relative URLs (about.html or ../page.html)
Add title attributes to links for additional information shown on hover

sub_topics.name: Link Targets and Types
sub_topics.short_description: Controlling how links open and creating different types of links.
example_tasks: Use target='_blank' to open links in new tabs or windows, and understand accessibility considerations
Create email links using mailto: protocol like <a href='mailto:email@example.com'>
Create anchor links that jump to specific sections within the same page using id attributes

sub_topics.name: Navigation Menus
sub_topics.short_description: Building navigation systems using lists and links within nav elements.
example_tasks: Create a navigation menu using <nav> element containing a <ul> list of links to site pages
Build a multi-level navigation menu with sub-menus using nested lists
Indicate the current page in navigation by adding classes or aria-current attributes for accessibility

sub_topics.name: Images and Media
sub_topics.short_description: Embedding images, audio, video, and other media content in web pages.

sub_topics.name: Adding Images
sub_topics.short_description: Embedding images using img tags with proper attributes for accessibility.
example_tasks: Add images using with descriptive alt text for accessibility
Control image display using width and height attributes to prevent layout shifts while images load
Understand image file formats (JPEG for photos, PNG for graphics with transparency, GIF for animations) and choose appropriately

sub_topics.name: Figures and Captions
sub_topics.short_description: Grouping images with captions using semantic HTML elements.
example_tasks: Use <figure> and <figcaption> elements to associate images with their captions semantically
Create photo galleries using multiple figure elements with descriptive captions
Understand when to use figure elements versus plain img tags based on whether captions are needed

sub_topics.name: Audio and Video Elements
sub_topics.short_description: Embedding audio and video content using HTML5 media elements.
example_tasks: Add video using <video src='file.mp4' controls> with controls for play, pause, and volume
Embed audio using <audio src='file.mp3' controls> for music or sound files
Add multiple source elements with different formats for browser compatibility and include text fallback

sub_topics.name: Embedding External Content
sub_topics.short_description: Using iframes to embed external content like videos, maps, and other websites.
example_tasks: Embed YouTube videos by copying the iframe embed code from YouTube and pasting into HTML
Embed Google Maps using iframe embed code to show locations on web pages
Understand security implications of iframes and when they are appropriate to use

sub_topics.name: HTML Tables
sub_topics.short_description: Creating tables to display tabular data with proper structure and accessibility.

sub_topics.name: Basic Table Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Creating tables using table, tr, th, and td elements.
example_tasks: Create basic tables using <table>, <tr> for rows, <th> for headers, and <td> for data cells
Build a schedule, grade sheet, or comparison table organizing information in rows and columns
Add borders and spacing to tables to make data more readable

sub_topics.name: Table Sections and Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Organizing tables using thead, tbody, and tfoot for better structure.
example_tasks: Divide tables into sections using <thead> for headers, <tbody> for main content, and <tfoot> for totals or summaries
Create complex tables with column spans using colspan and row spans using rowspan attributes
Add captions to tables using <caption> element to describe table purpose

sub_topics.name: Table Accessibility
sub_topics.short_description: Making tables accessible using scope attributes and proper headers.
example_tasks: Add scope='col' to column headers and scope='row' to row headers for screen reader accessibility
Create tables that work well on mobile devices by considering responsive design
Understand when tables are appropriate (tabular data) versus when CSS layout is better (page structure)

sub_topics.name: Forms and User Input
sub_topics.short_description: Creating forms to collect user input with various input types and proper structure.

sub_topics.name: Basic Form Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Creating forms with form elements, labels, and basic input fields.
example_tasks: Create forms using <form> element with action (where to send data) and method (GET or POST) attributes
Add text inputs using <input type='text'> and associate them with <label> elements for accessibility
Include submit buttons using <input type='submit'> or <button> to allow users to send form data

sub_topics.name: Input Types and Controls
sub_topics.short_description: Using different input types for various data including text, email, numbers, dates, and more.
example_tasks: Use specialized input types: email, password, number, date, tel, url to get appropriate keyboards on mobile devices
Add radio buttons for single-choice selections and checkboxes for multiple-choice selections
Create dropdown menus using <select> and <option> elements for choosing from predefined options

sub_topics.name: Text Areas and Large Input
sub_topics.short_description: Using textarea elements for multi-line text input.
example_tasks: Add <textarea> elements for comments, messages, or other multi-line text input
Control textarea size using rows and cols attributes or CSS
Make textareas user-friendly by allowing resizing and providing character count if needed

sub_topics.name: HTML Form Validation
sub_topics.short_description: Using HTML5 validation attributes to ensure proper data entry.
example_tasks: Add required attribute to make fields mandatory before form submission
Use pattern attribute with regular expressions to validate input formats like phone numbers or postal codes
Set min, max, and maxlength attributes to control numeric ranges and text length

sub_topics.name: Semantic HTML and Page Structure
sub_topics.short_description: Using semantic elements to create meaningful, accessible, and SEO-friendly page structures.

sub_topics.name: Semantic Structure Elements
sub_topics.short_description: Using header, nav, main, article, section, aside, and footer for page organization.
example_tasks: Structure pages using semantic elements: <header> for site header, <nav> for navigation, <main> for main content
Use <article> for self-contained content and <section> for thematic grouping within articles or pages
Add <aside> for sidebars or supplementary content and <footer> for page footer information

sub_topics.name: Creating Document Outlines
sub_topics.short_description: Building logical document hierarchies using semantic elements and headings.
example_tasks: Create a complete page structure with header, navigation, main content area, sidebar, and footer using semantic HTML
Build a blog post or article using article, section, and appropriate heading levels for clear hierarchy
Validate document outlines to ensure logical structure that helps screen readers and search engines

sub_topics.name: Accessibility Attributes
sub_topics.short_description: Adding ARIA attributes and other accessibility features to improve usability.
example_tasks: Add alt text to all images with meaningful descriptions, leaving alt='' for decorative images
Use aria-label and aria-describedby attributes to provide additional context for screen readers
Ensure proper heading hierarchy, landmark regions, and keyboard navigation for accessibility

name: CSS Styling and Layout
short_description: Students learn to style web pages using CSS selectors, properties, colors, fonts, spacing, and layout techniques including flexbox and responsive design.

sub_topics.name: CSS Basics and Syntax
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding CSS purpose, syntax, and methods for applying styles to HTML elements.

sub_topics.name: Introduction to CSS
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding CSS purpose and how it separates presentation from content.
example_tasks: Explain what CSS stands for (Cascading Style Sheets) and its role in controlling web page appearance
View websites with CSS disabled to understand the separation between HTML structure and CSS presentation
Understand the cascade concept where later styles override earlier ones and specificity determines which rules apply

sub_topics.name: CSS Syntax and Rules
sub_topics.short_description: Writing CSS rules with selectors, properties, and values.
example_tasks: Write CSS rules following the syntax: selector { property: value; } with proper punctuation
Create multiple declarations within a single rule using semicolons to separate property-value pairs
Use browser developer tools to inspect elements and see which CSS rules are applied

sub_topics.name: Methods of Applying CSS
sub_topics.short_description: Adding CSS to HTML using inline, internal, and external stylesheets.
example_tasks: Apply inline styles using style attributes directly on HTML elements (not recommended for production)
Create internal stylesheets using <style> tags in the HTML head section
Link external CSS files using <link rel='stylesheet' href='styles.css'> in the HTML head (best practice)

sub_topics.name: CSS Selectors
sub_topics.short_description: Targeting HTML elements using various selector types including element, class, ID, and advanced selectors.

sub_topics.name: Basic Selectors
sub_topics.short_description: Using element, class, and ID selectors to target HTML elements.
example_tasks: Use element selectors to style all elements of a type like p { color: blue; } for all paragraphs
Create class selectors with .classname to style groups of elements with shared styling
Use ID selectors with #idname to style unique elements, understanding that IDs should be unique per page

sub_topics.name: Combinators and Relationships
sub_topics.short_description: Selecting elements based on their relationships to other elements.
example_tasks: Use descendant selectors (div p) to select elements inside other elements regardless of depth
Apply child selectors (div > p) to select direct children only
Use adjacent sibling (+) and general sibling (~) selectors to target elements based on their position

sub_topics.name: Pseudo-classes
sub_topics.short_description: Styling elements based on their state or position using pseudo-classes.
example_tasks: Style link states using :hover, :active, :visited, and :focus pseudo-classes
Use structural pseudo-classes like :first-child, :last-child, :nth-child() to target specific elements
Apply :not() pseudo-class to exclude elements from selection

sub_topics.name: Attribute Selectors
sub_topics.short_description: Selecting elements based on their attributes and attribute values.
example_tasks: Select elements with specific attributes like [type='text'] to style all text inputs
Use attribute selectors with partial matching like [href^='https'] for external links
Combine attribute selectors with other selectors for precise targeting

sub_topics.name: Colors and Backgrounds
sub_topics.short_description: Applying colors to text and backgrounds using various color formats and background properties.

sub_topics.name: Color Formats and Values
sub_topics.short_description: Using different color formats including named colors, hex, RGB, and RGBA.
example_tasks: Apply colors using color names (red, blue), hex codes (#FF0000), and RGB values rgb(255, 0, 0)
Use RGBA and HSLA for colors with transparency by adding alpha channel values
Create color schemes using online tools and apply consistent colors throughout websites

sub_topics.name: Text Color and Styling
sub_topics.short_description: Changing text colors and ensuring readable contrast.
example_tasks: Set text color using the color property and ensure sufficient contrast with background for readability
Apply different colors to links in various states (normal, hover, visited) for clear user feedback
Test color contrast using accessibility tools to meet WCAG standards for text visibility

sub_topics.name: Background Colors and Images
sub_topics.short_description: Setting background colors and images with control over positioning and repetition.
example_tasks: Set background colors using background-color property for elements and page backgrounds
Add background images using background-image: url() and control repetition with background-repeat
Control background image positioning using background-position and sizing with background-size (cover, contain)

sub_topics.name: Typography and Text Styling
sub_topics.short_description: Styling text using fonts, sizes, spacing, alignment, and text effects.

sub_topics.name: Font Families and Web Fonts
sub_topics.short_description: Choosing and applying fonts including web-safe fonts and custom web fonts.
example_tasks: Apply font families using font-family property with fallback fonts like 'Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif'
Import Google Fonts or other web fonts using @import or <link> tags and apply them to text
Understand web-safe fonts versus custom fonts and when to use each

sub_topics.name: Text Size, Weight, and Style
sub_topics.short_description: Controlling text size, weight, style, and transformation.
example_tasks: Set text size using font-size with units like px, em, rem, or percentages
Control font weight using font-weight (normal, bold, 100-900) and style using font-style (italic, oblique)
Transform text using text-transform (uppercase, lowercase, capitalize) for consistent styling

sub_topics.name: Text Spacing and Alignment
sub_topics.short_description: Adjusting line height, letter spacing, word spacing, and text alignment.
example_tasks: Improve readability using line-height to adjust spacing between lines of text
Set text alignment using text-align (left, right, center, justify) for different layouts
Fine-tune typography using letter-spacing and word-spacing for professional appearance

sub_topics.name: Text Decoration and Effects
sub_topics.short_description: Adding underlines, shadows, and other text effects.
example_tasks: Add or remove underlines using text-decoration property (underline, none, line-through)
Create text shadows using text-shadow for depth and visual interest
Style text with effects while maintaining readability and accessibility

sub_topics.name: CSS Box Model
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how elements are sized using content, padding, border, and margin.

sub_topics.name: Understanding the Box Model
sub_topics.short_description: Learning how content, padding, border, and margin combine to size elements.
example_tasks: Visualize the box model using browser developer tools to see content, padding, border, and margin layers
Calculate total element size by adding width + padding + border + margin
Understand box-sizing property and difference between content-box (default) and border-box

sub_topics.name: Width and Height
sub_topics.short_description: Setting element dimensions using width and height properties.
example_tasks: Set element dimensions using width and height properties with various units (px, %, em, vw, vh)
Use min-width, max-width, min-height, max-height for responsive sizing constraints
Control how content behaves when it exceeds element size using overflow property

sub_topics.name: Padding
sub_topics.short_description: Adding space between content and border using padding properties.
example_tasks: Add padding inside elements using padding property (all sides) or padding-top, padding-right, padding-bottom, padding-left
Use shorthand padding: 10px 20px (vertical horizontal) or padding: 10px 20px 30px 40px (top right bottom left)
Create comfortable spacing around text and content using appropriate padding values

sub_topics.name: Borders
sub_topics.short_description: Adding borders around elements with control over width, style, and color.
example_tasks: Add borders using border property combining width, style (solid, dashed, dotted), and color
Style individual borders using border-top, border-right, border-bottom, border-left
Create rounded corners using border-radius for modern, polished designs

sub_topics.name: Margins
sub_topics.short_description: Adding space between elements using margin properties.
example_tasks: Add space between elements using margin property for all sides or individual sides (margin-top, etc.)
Center block elements horizontally using margin: 0 auto with specified width
Understand margin collapse where vertical margins between elements combine rather than add

sub_topics.name: Layout and Positioning
sub_topics.short_description: Controlling element placement using display types, position properties, and layout techniques.

sub_topics.name: Display Property
sub_topics.short_description: Controlling how elements are displayed using block, inline, inline-block, and none.
example_tasks: Understand difference between block elements (take full width, stack vertically) and inline elements (flow with text)
Use display: inline-block to create inline elements that accept width and height
Hide elements using display: none (removes from layout) versus visibility: hidden (keeps space)

sub_topics.name: Position Property
sub_topics.short_description: Positioning elements using static, relative, absolute, fixed, and sticky.
example_tasks: Use position: relative to offset elements from their normal position using top, right, bottom, left
Create absolutely positioned elements (position: absolute) positioned relative to nearest positioned ancestor
Make headers or navigation stick to viewport using position: fixed or position: sticky

sub_topics.name: Float and Clear
sub_topics.short_description: Floating elements and clearing floats for text wrapping and basic layouts.
example_tasks: Float images left or right to wrap text around them using float: left or float: right
Clear floats using clear: both to prevent elements from wrapping around floated elements
Understand clearfix techniques to contain floated elements within parent containers

sub_topics.name: Flexbox Layout
sub_topics.short_description: Creating flexible, responsive layouts using CSS Flexbox for distributing space and aligning items.

sub_topics.name: Flex Containers and Direction
sub_topics.short_description: Creating flex containers and controlling layout direction.
example_tasks: Create flex containers using display: flex to enable flexbox layout for child elements
Control layout direction using flex-direction: row (horizontal) or column (vertical)
Understand how flex containers affect only direct children, not all descendants

sub_topics.name: Flexbox Alignment
sub_topics.short_description: Aligning and distributing flex items using justify-content and align-items.
example_tasks: Distribute space along main axis using justify-content: flex-start, center, flex-end, space-between, space-around
Align items along cross axis using align-items: flex-start, center, flex-end, stretch
Create centered layouts both horizontally and vertically using flexbox alignment properties

sub_topics.name: Flex Items and Growth
sub_topics.short_description: Controlling individual flex item sizing using flex-grow, flex-shrink, and flex-basis.
example_tasks: Use flex-grow to make items grow and fill available space proportionally
Control item shrinking using flex-shrink when container is too small
Set initial sizes using flex-basis before growing or shrinking occurs

sub_topics.name: Creating Flex Layouts
sub_topics.short_description: Building common layouts using flexbox including navigation, cards, and page structures.
example_tasks: Create horizontal navigation menus using flexbox with evenly spaced links
Build card layouts with equal-height cards using flexbox alignment and flex properties
Design responsive page layouts with header, main content, sidebar, and footer using flexbox

sub_topics.name: Responsive Design
sub_topics.short_description: Creating websites that adapt to different screen sizes using media queries and flexible layouts.

sub_topics.name: Viewport and Relative Units
sub_topics.short_description: Using responsive units like percentages, em, rem, and viewport units.
example_tasks: Use relative units like percentages, em, and rem instead of fixed pixels for flexible sizing
Apply viewport units (vw, vh) to size elements relative to browser window size
Add viewport meta tag <meta name='viewport' content='width=device-width, initial-scale=1'> for proper mobile display

sub_topics.name: Media Queries
sub_topics.short_description: Applying different styles based on screen size, orientation, or device features.
example_tasks: Create media queries using @media (max-width: 768px) to apply styles for screens below specified width
Design mobile-first by starting with mobile styles and using min-width media queries for larger screens
Add breakpoints for common device sizes (mobile, tablet, desktop) to optimize layouts

sub_topics.name: Responsive Images and Media
sub_topics.short_description: Making images and media adapt to container sizes.
example_tasks: Make images responsive using max-width: 100% and height: auto to scale within containers
Use CSS to control video and iframe sizing to prevent overflow on small screens
Implement responsive images that load different sizes based on device using srcset attribute

sub_topics.name: Responsive Layout Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Creating layouts that reorganize for different screen sizes.
example_tasks: Create layouts that stack vertically on mobile and display side-by-side on desktop using flexbox and media queries
Build navigation that changes from horizontal desktop menu to hamburger menu on mobile
Design card grids that adjust column count based on available space

name: Web Development Projects
short_description: Students integrate HTML, CSS, and JavaScript skills to build complete, functional websites including personal portfolios, interactive pages, and multi-page sites.

sub_topics.name: Web Project Planning
sub_topics.short_description: Planning website structure, content, and design before development.

sub_topics.name: Site Structure and Navigation
sub_topics.short_description: Planning page hierarchy, navigation structure, and information architecture.
example_tasks: Create a site map showing all pages and how they connect through navigation
Plan content organization deciding what information goes on which pages
Design navigation structure ensuring users can easily find any page within 3 clicks

sub_topics.name: Wireframing and Mockups
sub_topics.short_description: Sketching layouts and designs before coding.
example_tasks: Create wireframes sketching page layouts showing placement of header, navigation, content, sidebar, and footer
Design mockups with more detail including colors, fonts, and spacing decisions
Plan responsive layouts showing how designs adapt to mobile, tablet, and desktop screens

sub_topics.name: Content Planning
sub_topics.short_description: Planning and gathering content including text, images, and media.
example_tasks: Write content for website pages ensuring clear, concise, and appropriate language for audience
Gather or create images, ensuring proper licensing and optimization for web use
Plan multimedia content like videos or audio and how they integrate into pages

sub_topics.name: Personal Portfolio Websites
sub_topics.short_description: Building portfolio websites showcasing skills, projects, and information.

sub_topics.name: Portfolio Structure and Content
sub_topics.short_description: Organizing portfolio pages including about, projects, and contact sections.
example_tasks: Create an about page with bio, skills, interests, and photo
Build a projects page showcasing coding projects, designs, or other work with descriptions and screenshots
Add a contact page with contact form or contact information and social media links

sub_topics.name: Portfolio Design and Branding
sub_topics.short_description: Designing visually appealing portfolios with consistent branding.
example_tasks: Choose color scheme and typography that reflects personal brand or style
Design a header with name/logo and consistent navigation across all pages
Create a cohesive visual identity using consistent spacing, colors, and design elements throughout site

sub_topics.name: Showcasing Projects Effectively
sub_topics.short_description: Presenting projects with descriptions, images, and links.
example_tasks: Create project cards or sections with titles, descriptions, screenshots, and links to live sites or code
Add hover effects or interactions to make project showcase engaging
Organize projects by category, date, or featured status for easy browsing

sub_topics.name: Interactive Web Pages
sub_topics.short_description: Building pages with JavaScript interactivity including forms, animations, and dynamic content.

sub_topics.name: Interactive Forms and Validation
sub_topics.short_description: Creating forms with JavaScript validation and user feedback.
example_tasks: Build contact forms with JavaScript validation checking for required fields, email format, and message length
Display error messages or success messages based on form validation results
Create survey or quiz forms that calculate results and display feedback using JavaScript

sub_topics.name: Dynamic Content Loading
sub_topics.short_description: Changing page content based on user interactions without page reload.
example_tasks: Create tabbed interfaces where clicking tabs displays different content sections
Build accordion sections that expand and collapse when clicked
Design image galleries with lightbox effects showing full-size images on click

sub_topics.name: Animations and Visual Effects
sub_topics.short_description: Adding CSS and JavaScript animations to enhance user experience.
example_tasks: Create smooth scroll effects when clicking anchor links to sections on the page
Add fade-in animations to elements as they enter the viewport during scrolling
Build interactive hover effects, button animations, and loading indicators

sub_topics.name: Multi-Page Websites
sub_topics.short_description: Creating websites with multiple linked pages and consistent design.

sub_topics.name: Maintaining Design Consistency
sub_topics.short_description: Using consistent styles, navigation, and structure across pages.
example_tasks: Create a shared stylesheet used by all pages to ensure consistent fonts, colors, and spacing
Use identical header and navigation on all pages so users always know how to move around the site
Maintain consistent layout patterns and content organization across pages

sub_topics.name: File and Folder Organization
sub_topics.short_description: Organizing website files in logical folder structures.
example_tasks: Organize site files into folders like /css, /images, /js, and /pages for clean structure
Use relative links correctly to connect pages, stylesheets, scripts, and images
Follow naming conventions using lowercase, hyphens, and descriptive names for all files

sub_topics.name: Multi-Level Navigation
sub_topics.short_description: Creating navigation systems for sites with multiple sections and sub-pages.
example_tasks: Build drop-down menus using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript for multi-level navigation
Add breadcrumb navigation showing users their current location in site hierarchy
Create footer navigation with additional links to secondary pages like privacy policy or site map

sub_topics.name: Publishing and Deployment
sub_topics.short_description: Preparing websites for publication and deploying them to web servers.

sub_topics.name: Testing and Optimization
sub_topics.short_description: Testing websites across browsers and devices before launch.
example_tasks: Test websites in different browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge) to ensure consistent appearance and functionality
Check responsive design on various device sizes using browser developer tools
Validate HTML and CSS code using W3C validators to catch errors before deployment

sub_topics.name: Web Hosting and Domains
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how websites are hosted and accessed via domain names.
example_tasks: Research different web hosting options including free hosting services like GitHub Pages, Netlify, or Replit
Understand how domain names work and how they point to servers hosting websites
Learn about file transfer protocols (FTP) for uploading website files to servers

sub_topics.name: Deploying with GitHub Pages
sub_topics.short_description: Publishing websites using GitHub Pages hosting service.
example_tasks: Create a GitHub repository for website code and enable GitHub Pages in repository settings
Upload website files to GitHub and access the live site at username.github.io/repository-name
Update websites by pushing changes to GitHub and seeing updates reflected automatically

name: Introduction to Backend Development
short_description: Students gain foundational understanding of server-side programming, client-server architecture, APIs, and how frontend and backend work together.

sub_topics.name: Client-Server Architecture
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how clients request data and servers respond in web applications.

sub_topics.name: Frontend vs Backend Roles
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the distinction between client-side and server-side code.
example_tasks: Identify which tasks happen on the frontend (user interface, user interactions) versus backend (data storage, business logic)
Trace the flow of data in a web application from user action through frontend to backend and back
Understand why sensitive operations like password verification must happen on the backend for security

sub_topics.name: HTTP Requests and Responses
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how browsers communicate with servers using HTTP protocol.
example_tasks: Identify different HTTP methods (GET for retrieving data, POST for sending data, PUT for updating, DELETE for removing)
Examine HTTP requests and responses using browser developer tools Network tab
Understand request headers, response headers, status codes (200 OK, 404 Not Found, 500 Server Error)

sub_topics.name: Stateless Protocol and Sessions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding HTTP's stateless nature and how servers maintain user sessions.
example_tasks: Explain why HTTP is stateless (each request is independent) and challenges this creates
Understand how cookies store session identifiers to maintain user state across requests
Learn how servers use sessions to remember user login status and shopping cart contents

sub_topics.name: Introduction to APIs
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Application Programming Interfaces and how applications communicate.

sub_topics.name: What are APIs
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding API concepts and why they're important for modern web development.
example_tasks: Explain what API stands for (Application Programming Interface) and its role in allowing programs to communicate
Identify examples of popular APIs like Google Maps API, Weather API, Social Media APIs and what they provide
Understand the concept of API endpoints as specific URLs that provide different data or functions

sub_topics.name: REST APIs and JSON
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding RESTful API architecture and JSON data format.
example_tasks: Learn REST principles including using HTTP methods appropriately and organizing endpoints logically
Work with JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) to understand how data is structured and transmitted
Parse JSON data received from APIs and extract needed information for display

sub_topics.name: Consuming APIs in Frontend
sub_topics.short_description: Making API requests from JavaScript to retrieve and display data.
example_tasks: Use fetch() or similar methods to make GET requests to public APIs and retrieve data
Display API data on web pages by parsing JSON responses and creating HTML elements dynamically
Handle API errors gracefully and display appropriate messages to users when requests fail

sub_topics.name: API Authentication Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how APIs verify identity using API keys and tokens.
example_tasks: Register for API keys from public APIs and understand how to include them in requests
Understand why API keys should be kept secure and not committed to public code repositories
Learn basic authentication methods like API keys in headers or query parameters

sub_topics.name: Server-Side Concepts
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding basic server-side programming concepts including routing, templates, and data handling.

sub_topics.name: Routing and URL Handling
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how servers map URLs to different pages or functions.
example_tasks: Understand how different URLs (routes) on a website trigger different server responses
Map out routing structure for a simple website showing which URLs display which content
Learn about URL parameters and query strings for passing data in URLs

sub_topics.name: Server-Side Templates
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how servers generate HTML dynamically using templates.
example_tasks: Understand the concept of templates that combine static HTML with dynamic data
Learn how template engines insert variable data into HTML to create personalized pages
Compare static HTML files versus dynamically generated pages from templates

sub_topics.name: Processing Form Data
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how servers receive and process data submitted through forms.
example_tasks: Trace the flow of form data from HTML form submission to server-side processing
Understand the difference between GET and POST methods for sending form data
Learn about server-side validation and why it's necessary in addition to frontend validation

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Databases
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how servers store and retrieve data from databases.

sub_topics.name: Why Databases are Needed
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the need for persistent data storage in applications.
example_tasks: Explain why websites need databases to store user accounts, posts, products, and other data
Compare storing data in files versus databases, understanding benefits of databases
Identify what data in common websites would be stored in databases (user profiles, comments, orders)

sub_topics.name: Types of Databases
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding relational databases versus NoSQL databases.
example_tasks: Learn about relational databases (SQL) that organize data in tables with relationships
Understand NoSQL databases that store data in flexible formats like documents or key-value pairs
Compare database types and when each is appropriate based on data structure needs

sub_topics.name: CRUD Operations Concept
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Create, Read, Update, Delete operations on data.
example_tasks: Identify CRUD operations in common web applications (creating posts, reading user profiles, updating settings, deleting comments)
Map user actions in applications to corresponding CRUD operations on backend
Understand that most applications are built around CRUD operations on different types of data

name: Digital Media and Content Creation
short_description: Students create and edit digital media including graphics, audio, video, and integrate multimedia content into web projects with attention to quality and optimization.

sub_topics.name: Image Creation and Editing
sub_topics.short_description: Creating and editing digital images for web and other digital projects.

sub_topics.name: Image File Formats
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding different image formats and when to use each.
example_tasks: Compare JPEG (photos, no transparency), PNG (graphics with transparency), GIF (animations), and SVG (scalable vector graphics)
Choose appropriate image formats based on content type, transparency needs, and file size constraints
Convert between image formats using online tools or image editors and observe quality and file size differences

sub_topics.name: Image Editing Software
sub_topics.short_description: Using image editing tools to modify and enhance images.
example_tasks: Use image editing software (GIMP, Photopea, Canva, or similar) to crop, resize, and rotate images
Adjust brightness, contrast, and color balance to improve image appearance
Remove backgrounds, add text overlays, and apply filters for various effects

sub_topics.name: Basic Graphic Design
sub_topics.short_description: Creating graphics, logos, and visual elements for digital projects.
example_tasks: Design logos or headers for websites using basic shapes, text, and colors
Create graphics for social media posts, presentations, or website banners
Apply design principles like contrast, alignment, and visual hierarchy to create effective graphics

sub_topics.name: Image Optimization for Web
sub_topics.short_description: Optimizing images for fast loading without sacrificing quality.
example_tasks: Resize images to appropriate dimensions for web display before uploading
Compress images using tools to reduce file size while maintaining acceptable quality
Use appropriate formats and quality settings to balance image quality with load time

sub_topics.name: Audio Creation and Editing
sub_topics.short_description: Recording, editing, and incorporating audio content in digital projects.

sub_topics.name: Audio File Formats
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding audio formats like MP3, WAV, and AAC.
example_tasks: Compare audio formats: MP3 (compressed, smaller files), WAV (uncompressed, high quality), AAC (modern compression)
Choose appropriate audio formats based on quality needs and file size constraints
Convert between audio formats using online converters or audio software

sub_topics.name: Recording and Capturing Audio
sub_topics.short_description: Recording voice, music, or other audio using microphones and recording software.
example_tasks: Record narration or voiceovers using computer microphone and recording software (Audacity or similar)
Understand basic recording principles like microphone placement, room acoustics, and noise reduction
Capture audio at appropriate quality settings considering intended use and file size

sub_topics.name: Audio Editing Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Editing audio clips including trimming, combining, and applying effects.
example_tasks: Use audio editing software to cut, trim, and combine audio clips
Adjust volume levels and normalize audio for consistent loudness
Apply basic effects like fade in/out, noise removal, and equalization

sub_topics.name: Adding Audio to Web Projects
sub_topics.short_description: Integrating audio content into websites and applications.
example_tasks: Embed audio players in web pages using HTML5 audio element with controls
Provide audio alternatives for accessibility including transcripts for audio content
Optimize audio files for web delivery balancing quality and file size

sub_topics.name: Video Creation and Editing
sub_topics.short_description: Creating, editing, and publishing video content for digital platforms.

sub_topics.name: Video File Formats and Codecs
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding video formats like MP4, WebM, and MOV.
example_tasks: Compare common video formats: MP4 (most compatible), WebM (web-optimized), MOV (Apple)
Understand video codecs (H.264, H.265, VP9) and how they compress video data
Choose appropriate video formats for different platforms (web, mobile, desktop)

sub_topics.name: Video Recording and Screen Capture
sub_topics.short_description: Recording video using cameras or screen recording software.
example_tasks: Record video using webcams or smartphones with attention to lighting, framing, and audio quality
Create screen capture videos demonstrating software or explaining concepts using screen recording tools
Understand basic videography principles like rule of thirds, lighting, and audio quality

sub_topics.name: Video Editing Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Editing videos including cutting, transitions, and adding elements.
example_tasks: Use video editing software to trim clips, remove unwanted sections, and arrange clips in sequence
Add transitions between clips, text overlays, and titles to videos
Combine video clips with audio tracks, adjusting audio levels for background music and dialogue

sub_topics.name: Publishing Video Online
sub_topics.short_description: Optimizing and embedding videos in websites and uploading to platforms.
example_tasks: Embed videos in web pages using HTML5 video element or iframe embeds from YouTube/Vimeo
Optimize videos for web by choosing appropriate resolutions, bitrates, and compression settings
Upload videos to platforms like YouTube with appropriate titles, descriptions, and tags

sub_topics.name: Multimedia Integration
sub_topics.short_description: Combining multiple media types in cohesive digital projects.

sub_topics.name: Planning Multimedia Projects
sub_topics.short_description: Planning projects that effectively combine images, audio, video, and text.
example_tasks: Storyboard multimedia projects planning what media appears when and how elements connect
Create asset lists identifying all media needed and sources for each element
Plan user experience considering how users will interact with and navigate multimedia content

sub_topics.name: Multimedia Presentations
sub_topics.short_description: Creating presentations with integrated media using presentation software.
example_tasks: Build presentations combining text, images, audio, and video effectively without overwhelming slides
Design consistent visual themes using appropriate colors, fonts, and layouts
Present information clearly with good use of visuals to support rather than duplicate spoken content

sub_topics.name: Interactive Multimedia
sub_topics.short_description: Creating interactive experiences combining media with user interaction.
example_tasks: Build interactive web pages with images, videos, and animations that respond to user actions
Create clickable image maps or hotspots that reveal information or navigate to content
Design multimedia experiences with clear navigation and intuitive user interfaces

sub_topics.name: Copyright and Attribution
sub_topics.short_description: Using media legally and providing proper attribution.
example_tasks: Find Creative Commons licensed media for use in projects and provide proper attribution
Create original media content to avoid copyright issues when possible
Document sources for all media used in projects including images, audio, video, and fonts

name: Database Concepts and SQL
short_description: Students learn database design principles, create and manage relational databases, write SQL queries to retrieve and manipulate data, and understand relationships between tables.

sub_topics.name: Relational Database Fundamentals
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how relational databases organize data in tables with rows and columns.

sub_topics.name: Database Structure and Terminology
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding tables, rows, columns, and primary keys in database organization.
example_tasks: Identify the components of a database table: table name, column names (fields), rows (records), and data types
Understand that each row represents one record (like one student or one product) and columns represent attributes
Define primary keys as unique identifiers for each row in a table and explain why they're necessary

sub_topics.name: Database Data Types
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding different data types used in databases for storing various kinds of information.
example_tasks: Identify common database data types: INTEGER for whole numbers, REAL/FLOAT for decimals, TEXT/VARCHAR for strings, DATE for dates
Choose appropriate data types for different kinds of information like ages (INTEGER), names (TEXT), prices (REAL), birthdates (DATE)
Understand constraints on data types and why choosing correct types helps maintain data quality

sub_topics.name: Database Design Principles
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how to design effective database structures that minimize redundancy.
example_tasks: Design a simple database schema for a scenario like a school (students table, classes table, enrollments table)
Identify redundant data in poorly designed databases and restructure to eliminate duplication
Apply normalization principles to organize data efficiently by separating information into appropriate tables

sub_topics.name: SQL Query Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Writing SQL queries to retrieve data from databases using SELECT statements.

sub_topics.name: SELECT Statements
sub_topics.short_description: Retrieving data from database tables using SELECT queries.
example_tasks: Write SELECT queries to retrieve all columns using SELECT * FROM table_name
Select specific columns using SELECT column1, column2 FROM table_name to retrieve only needed data
Use DISTINCT keyword to eliminate duplicate values in query results

sub_topics.name: Filtering with WHERE Clause
sub_topics.short_description: Using WHERE clauses to filter query results based on conditions.
example_tasks: Add WHERE clauses to filter results using conditions like WHERE age > 12 or WHERE name = 'Alex'
Combine multiple conditions using AND, OR, and NOT operators in WHERE clauses
Use comparison operators (=, !=, <, >, <=, >=) and pattern matching with LIKE operator

sub_topics.name: Sorting and Limiting Results
sub_topics.short_description: Organizing query results using ORDER BY and LIMIT clauses.
example_tasks: Sort query results using ORDER BY column_name ASC (ascending) or DESC (descending)
Limit number of results returned using LIMIT clause like LIMIT 10 for top 10 results
Combine ORDER BY and LIMIT to get top or bottom results like highest scores or most recent dates

sub_topics.name: Aggregate Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Using functions to calculate summaries like COUNT, SUM, AVG, MAX, MIN.
example_tasks: Use COUNT(*) to count number of rows or COUNT(column) to count non-null values
Calculate totals using SUM(), averages using AVG(), maximum using MAX(), and minimum using MIN()
Use GROUP BY to calculate aggregates for different categories like average score per class

sub_topics.name: Table Relationships and Joins
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding and implementing relationships between tables using foreign keys and joins.

sub_topics.name: Foreign Keys and Relationships
sub_topics.short_description: Linking tables together using foreign keys to establish relationships.
example_tasks: Understand foreign keys as columns in one table that reference the primary key in another table
Identify one-to-many relationships like one teacher teaching many classes or one customer placing many orders
Design database schemas showing relationships between tables using foreign keys

sub_topics.name: Inner Joins
sub_topics.short_description: Combining data from multiple tables using INNER JOIN.
example_tasks: Write INNER JOIN queries to combine related data from two tables based on matching foreign keys
Retrieve data spanning multiple tables like student names with their enrolled classes
Understand that INNER JOIN only returns rows where matching records exist in both tables

sub_topics.name: Other Join Types
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding LEFT JOIN, RIGHT JOIN, and other join types.
example_tasks: Use LEFT JOIN to retrieve all rows from the left table even when no match exists in the right table
Compare INNER JOIN (only matching rows) versus LEFT JOIN (all left rows plus matches)
Write queries that retrieve data even when some relationships don't exist, like all students including those not enrolled in classes

sub_topics.name: Data Manipulation with SQL
sub_topics.short_description: Inserting, updating, and deleting data using SQL statements.

sub_topics.name: Inserting Data
sub_topics.short_description: Adding new records to database tables using INSERT statements.
example_tasks: Write INSERT statements to add new rows to tables like INSERT INTO students (name, age, grade) VALUES ('Alex', 13, 8)
Insert multiple rows in a single INSERT statement for efficiency
Understand data type requirements and constraints when inserting data

sub_topics.name: Updating Data
sub_topics.short_description: Modifying existing records using UPDATE statements.
example_tasks: Write UPDATE statements to change existing data like UPDATE students SET grade = 9 WHERE name = 'Alex'
Update multiple columns in a single UPDATE statement
Use WHERE clauses carefully in updates to avoid accidentally changing wrong records

sub_topics.name: Deleting Data
sub_topics.short_description: Removing records from tables using DELETE statements.
example_tasks: Write DELETE statements to remove rows like DELETE FROM students WHERE graduated = true
Understand the importance of WHERE clauses in DELETE to avoid deleting all data accidentally
Consider alternatives to deletion like marking records as inactive rather than permanently removing them

sub_topics.name: Database Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Designing and implementing databases for real-world scenarios.

sub_topics.name: Designing Database Schemas
sub_topics.short_description: Planning complete database structures for applications.
example_tasks: Design a database schema for a library system with books, members, and checkouts tables
Create an e-commerce database with products, customers, orders, and order_items tables
Diagram table relationships showing primary keys, foreign keys, and relationship types

sub_topics.name: Building Database Projects
sub_topics.short_description: Creating and populating databases with sample data for applications.
example_tasks: Create database tables using SQL CREATE TABLE statements with appropriate data types and constraints
Populate tables with sample data that represents realistic application scenarios
Write queries to answer questions about the data like 'Which students have perfect attendance?' or 'What are the top-selling products?'

sub_topics.name: Connecting Databases to Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how applications interact with databases through queries.
example_tasks: Trace how web applications use databases: user action triggers query, results displayed on page
Understand the role of backend code in constructing SQL queries based on user input
Design simple applications that would read from and write to databases like grade books or inventory systems

name: Data Analysis and Visualization
short_description: Students collect, organize, analyze, and visualize data to identify patterns, draw conclusions, and communicate findings effectively using spreadsheets and visualization tools.

sub_topics.name: Data Collection and Organization
sub_topics.short_description: Gathering data from various sources and organizing it for analysis.

sub_topics.name: Data Sources and Collection Methods
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding where data comes from and methods for collecting it.
example_tasks: Identify different data sources: surveys, sensors, web scraping, public datasets, APIs, direct observation
Design a survey to collect data about a topic of interest with clear questions and response formats
Understand ethical considerations in data collection including consent, privacy, and bias

sub_topics.name: Data Formats and File Types
sub_topics.short_description: Working with data in different formats including CSV, JSON, and spreadsheets.
example_tasks: Open and examine CSV files understanding comma-separated values format
Import data from CSV files into spreadsheet applications for analysis
Convert between data formats to make data compatible with different analysis tools

sub_topics.name: Organizing Data in Spreadsheets
sub_topics.short_description: Structuring data in rows and columns with appropriate headers and formatting.
example_tasks: Organize data with descriptive column headers and consistent data entry in each row
Clean data by removing duplicates, fixing inconsistencies, and handling missing values
Use appropriate data types in spreadsheet columns (numbers, dates, text) for correct calculations

sub_topics.name: Spreadsheet Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Using spreadsheet formulas and functions to calculate statistics and analyze data.

sub_topics.name: Basic Spreadsheet Formulas
sub_topics.short_description: Creating formulas for calculations using cell references and operators.
example_tasks: Write formulas using cell references like =A1+B1 instead of hardcoding numbers
Use arithmetic operators (+, -, *, /) in formulas to perform calculations
Copy formulas down columns or across rows and understand relative versus absolute cell references

sub_topics.name: Statistical Functions
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating statistics using built-in spreadsheet functions.
example_tasks: Use SUM(), AVERAGE(), COUNT(), MAX(), and MIN() functions to calculate basic statistics
Calculate median using MEDIAN() and mode using MODE() for different measures of center
Use COUNTIF() and SUMIF() to calculate statistics for data meeting specific criteria

sub_topics.name: Sorting and Filtering Data
sub_topics.short_description: Organizing and filtering data to focus on specific subsets.
example_tasks: Sort data by one or more columns to identify patterns or extremes
Apply filters to show only rows meeting certain criteria like scores above 90 or dates in a range
Use filtering to analyze subsets of data separately like comparing different groups

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Pivot Tables
sub_topics.short_description: Creating pivot tables to summarize and reorganize data.
example_tasks: Create simple pivot tables to summarize data by categories like total sales by product or average scores by class
Use pivot tables to count occurrences of different values or calculate category totals
Understand how pivot tables reorganize data to show different perspectives

sub_topics.name: Data Visualization
sub_topics.short_description: Creating charts and graphs to visually represent data and communicate findings.

sub_topics.name: Choosing Appropriate Chart Types
sub_topics.short_description: Selecting the right visualization for different types of data and questions.
example_tasks: Use bar charts to compare values across categories like sales by product or scores by student
Create line charts to show trends over time like temperature changes or website traffic
Use pie charts to show parts of a whole when there are limited categories with clear proportions

sub_topics.name: Creating Charts in Spreadsheets
sub_topics.short_description: Building charts from spreadsheet data with appropriate settings.
example_tasks: Select data ranges and create charts using spreadsheet chart tools
Customize chart titles, axis labels, and legends to make visualizations clear and informative
Format charts with appropriate colors, scales, and layouts for readability

sub_topics.name: Principles of Effective Visualization
sub_topics.short_description: Designing visualizations that communicate clearly and avoid misleading representations.
example_tasks: Design charts with clear labels, appropriate scales, and descriptive titles
Avoid misleading visualizations like truncated axes or inappropriate 3D effects
Choose colors carefully considering colorblind accessibility and visual clarity

sub_topics.name: Advanced Chart Types
sub_topics.short_description: Creating scatter plots, histograms, and other specialized visualizations.
example_tasks: Create scatter plots to show relationships between two numeric variables
Build histograms to show distribution of values across ranges
Use combination charts when comparing different types of data on the same visualization

sub_topics.name: Interpreting and Communicating Data
sub_topics.short_description: Drawing conclusions from data analysis and presenting findings effectively.

sub_topics.name: Identifying Patterns and Trends
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing patterns, trends, outliers, and relationships in data.
example_tasks: Identify trends in data such as increasing, decreasing, or cyclical patterns
Spot outliers that differ significantly from other data points and investigate potential causes
Recognize correlations between variables though understanding correlation doesn't prove causation

sub_topics.name: Drawing Valid Conclusions
sub_topics.short_description: Making appropriate inferences from data while acknowledging limitations.
example_tasks: State conclusions supported by data evidence while avoiding overgeneralizations
Identify limitations of data like sample size, collection methods, or missing information
Distinguish between correlation and causation, avoiding claims of causation without evidence

sub_topics.name: Presenting Data Findings
sub_topics.short_description: Creating clear presentations that communicate data insights effectively.
example_tasks: Create data presentations combining visualizations with written explanations of key findings
Tell a story with data by organizing findings in logical order that builds understanding
Design presentations that highlight important insights without overwhelming audience with too much detail

name: Introduction to Data Science
short_description: Students explore data science concepts including statistical thinking, data cleaning, exploratory analysis, making predictions from data, and understanding machine learning basics.

sub_topics.name: Statistical Concepts
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding basic statistical concepts used in data analysis.

sub_topics.name: Measures of Center
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating and interpreting mean, median, and mode.
example_tasks: Calculate mean (average), median (middle value), and mode (most frequent) for datasets
Understand when each measure is most appropriate, like using median when outliers affect mean
Compare how mean and median differ for skewed versus symmetric distributions

sub_topics.name: Measures of Spread
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding range, quartiles, and standard deviation to describe data variation.
example_tasks: Calculate range (max - min) to understand the spread of data
Find quartiles and create box plots to visualize data distribution and identify outliers
Understand standard deviation as a measure of how spread out values are from the mean

sub_topics.name: Understanding Distributions
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing different distribution shapes and what they reveal about data.
example_tasks: Identify distribution shapes: symmetric, skewed left, skewed right, bimodal, uniform
Create histograms to visualize data distributions and identify patterns
Understand what distribution shape reveals about the data and appropriate statistics to use

sub_topics.name: Data Cleaning and Preparation
sub_topics.short_description: Preparing messy real-world data for analysis by handling errors, missing values, and inconsistencies.

sub_topics.name: Identifying Data Quality Issues
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing problems in datasets that need to be addressed.
example_tasks: Identify common data quality issues: missing values, duplicates, inconsistent formatting, outliers, incorrect data types
Examine datasets for errors like typos, impossible values, or inconsistent units
Document data quality issues found and plan cleaning strategies

sub_topics.name: Handling Missing Values
sub_topics.short_description: Dealing with incomplete data through various strategies.
example_tasks: Identify missing values in datasets and determine why data might be missing
Apply strategies for missing data: removing rows with missing values, filling with mean/median, or using placeholders
Understand trade-offs between different approaches to handling missing data

sub_topics.name: Data Transformation
sub_topics.short_description: Converting and standardizing data for consistent analysis.
example_tasks: Standardize text data like making all entries lowercase or fixing inconsistent capitalization
Convert data types such as strings to numbers or dates to standard formats
Create derived variables like calculating age from birthdate or categorizing continuous data into ranges

sub_topics.name: Exploratory Data Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Investigating datasets to discover patterns, relationships, and insights.

sub_topics.name: Asking Questions of Data
sub_topics.short_description: Formulating questions that can be answered through data analysis.
example_tasks: Generate questions about datasets that can be investigated through analysis
Transform general questions into specific, measurable questions answerable with available data
Prioritize questions based on importance and feasibility of answering with the data

sub_topics.name: Single Variable Analysis
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing individual variables to understand their distributions and characteristics.
example_tasks: Create frequency tables and histograms to understand how individual variables are distributed
Calculate summary statistics for single variables to describe their characteristics
Identify unusual values or patterns in individual variables

sub_topics.name: Analyzing Relationships
sub_topics.short_description: Investigating relationships between two variables.
example_tasks: Create scatter plots to visualize relationships between two numeric variables
Calculate correlation coefficients to quantify strength and direction of relationships
Use grouped bar charts or side-by-side box plots to compare groups

sub_topics.name: Predictions and Machine Learning Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how data can be used to make predictions and basic machine learning concepts.

sub_topics.name: Using Patterns to Predict
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how patterns in historical data can inform predictions.
example_tasks: Identify patterns in data that could be used to make predictions about future values
Understand the concept of training on historical data to predict new cases
Recognize limitations of predictions including that past patterns may not continue

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Classification
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how data can be used to classify items into categories.
example_tasks: Understand classification as predicting which category something belongs to based on its features
Explore simple classification rules based on data patterns like decision trees
Test classification accuracy by comparing predictions to actual categories

sub_topics.name: Basic Machine Learning Concepts
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding fundamental ideas behind machine learning without complex math.
example_tasks: Understand that machine learning involves computers finding patterns in data automatically
Explore supervised learning where algorithms learn from labeled examples
Discuss real-world applications of machine learning like recommendation systems, image recognition, or spam filters

sub_topics.name: Machine Learning Ethics and Bias
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding ethical considerations and potential biases in machine learning.
example_tasks: Identify how bias in training data can lead to biased predictions
Discuss ethical implications of machine learning in areas like facial recognition or criminal justice
Understand importance of diverse, representative training data for fair machine learning systems

name: Cybersecurity Principles
short_description: Students learn about cybersecurity threats, defensive strategies, encryption basics, secure coding practices, and protecting systems and data from attacks.

sub_topics.name: Cybersecurity Threat Landscape
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding different types of cyber threats and attack vectors.

sub_topics.name: Types of Cyber Threats
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying various categories of cybersecurity threats.
example_tasks: Research different threat categories: malware, social engineering, network attacks, insider threats, physical threats
Create a visual map of cyber threats showing how they target different parts of systems
Analyze recent news stories about cyber attacks and categorize the types of threats involved

sub_topics.name: Common Attack Vectors
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how attackers gain access to systems and data.
example_tasks: Identify common entry points for attacks: email phishing, vulnerable software, weak passwords, unpatched systems
Map out attack scenarios showing step-by-step how an attacker might compromise a system
Understand the concept of the attack surface and how to minimize it

sub_topics.name: Threat Actors and Motivations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding who launches cyber attacks and why.
example_tasks: Identify different threat actors: hacktivists, cybercriminals, nation-states, insider threats, script kiddies
Understand different motivations: financial gain, espionage, disruption, activism, curiosity
Discuss how understanding attacker motivations helps in planning defenses

sub_topics.name: Defensive Cybersecurity Strategies
sub_topics.short_description: Learning security principles and practices to protect systems and data.

sub_topics.name: Core Security Principles
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding fundamental concepts like defense in depth, least privilege, and fail-safe defaults.
example_tasks: Explain defense in depth using multiple layers of security like locks on doors, alarms, and security guards
Apply principle of least privilege by giving users only the permissions they need for their tasks
Understand fail-safe defaults where systems default to secure settings rather than convenient but insecure ones

sub_topics.name: Access Control and Authentication
sub_topics.short_description: Controlling who can access systems and data through authentication and authorization.
example_tasks: Understand the difference between authentication (proving identity) and authorization (granting permissions)
Implement strong authentication using passwords plus additional factors like codes or biometrics
Design access control systems that follow principle of least privilege for different user roles

sub_topics.name: Network Security Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how networks are secured through firewalls, encryption, and monitoring.
example_tasks: Understand how firewalls filter network traffic based on rules to block malicious connections
Learn about VPNs (Virtual Private Networks) that encrypt internet connections for security and privacy
Identify importance of network monitoring and intrusion detection systems

sub_topics.name: Software Updates and Patch Management
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the critical importance of keeping software updated.
example_tasks: Explain why software updates are critical for security, patching vulnerabilities that attackers exploit
Create a patch management plan for personal devices including checking for updates regularly
Research examples of major security breaches that exploited unpatched vulnerabilities

sub_topics.name: Encryption and Cryptography
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how encryption protects data and communications.

sub_topics.name: Encryption Fundamentals
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding basic concepts of encryption, keys, and ciphers.
example_tasks: Understand encryption as transforming data so only authorized parties with keys can read it
Explore simple ciphers like Caesar cipher to understand basic encryption concepts
Distinguish between encryption (reversible with key) and hashing (one-way transformation)

sub_topics.name: Symmetric vs Asymmetric Encryption
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding different encryption approaches and their uses.
example_tasks: Understand symmetric encryption where same key encrypts and decrypts (fast but requires shared secret key)
Learn about asymmetric encryption using public and private key pairs (solves key distribution problem)
Identify use cases for each type like HTTPS using both for secure web communication

sub_topics.name: Real-World Encryption Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding where encryption is used to protect data.
example_tasks: Identify encryption in daily use: HTTPS for websites, encrypted messaging apps, full-disk encryption on devices
Understand end-to-end encryption where only sender and recipient can read messages, not service providers
Discuss the balance between encryption for privacy and concerns about encrypted communications hiding illegal activity

sub_topics.name: Hashing and Data Integrity
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how hashing verifies data hasn't been tampered with.
example_tasks: Understand hashing as one-way transformation that creates unique fingerprints of data
Learn how hashes verify file integrity by comparing hash values before and after transfer
Understand password hashing where passwords are stored as hashes rather than plain text

sub_topics.name: Secure Coding Practices
sub_topics.short_description: Writing code that is resistant to common vulnerabilities and attacks.

sub_topics.name: Input Validation
sub_topics.short_description: Validating and sanitizing user input to prevent injection attacks.
example_tasks: Understand why trusting user input is dangerous and can lead to security vulnerabilities
Implement input validation checking that data is the expected type, length, and format
Learn about injection attacks where malicious input is interpreted as code, and how to prevent them

sub_topics.name: Common Security Vulnerabilities
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding frequent coding mistakes that create security holes.
example_tasks: Learn about SQL injection where malicious input manipulates database queries
Understand cross-site scripting (XSS) where attackers inject malicious scripts into web pages
Identify buffer overflows, authentication bypasses, and other common vulnerabilities

sub_topics.name: Security in Software Design
sub_topics.short_description: Building security considerations into software from the beginning.
example_tasks: Apply security by design principles planning security features from the start rather than adding them later
Identify sensitive data in applications and plan how to protect it through encryption and access controls
Create threat models for applications identifying potential attacks and planning defenses

sub_topics.name: Security Incidents and Response
